39470655.review:
Only people of a very specific age range are likely to get much out of this. A visual novel set in an IM client in the mid '00s about characters in their last year of high school. I have to say the writing and look/feel of the client are perfect. Janky sounding hard drive noises, horrible low-res avatars, cheesy song lyrics in profiles - It's MSN and AIM all over again.

The jist of it is you chat to two girls in your year, and eventually become girlfriend with one (or neither!).

It's cute, and as mentioned, the dialogue and writing is pretty much exactly how I remember all those awkward late night conversations being. Main problem being is it's not particularly stimulating as an adult, so near the end it got a little tedious. There aren't any twists and turns, and choosing the obviously 'correct' dialogue options leads to a happily ever after.

It's a cute little nostalgia indulgence for an evening. There are some secret conversations to do with various icons you set but you're probably not going to hunt them all down.

I highly recommend turning typing assist on in the settings.

39380534.review:
I'm going to recommend this with one really big catch that everyone should read before starting this game.
Each girl will ask you specific questions early in the game, and you HAVE to give the same answers to each of them. It sounds easy, and it is, especially in ones that just ask you what your favorite music or game is.
BUT, there is one specific question that has to do with family that each girl words completely differently. They sound like totally different questions, so naturally I answered differently. However, that ruined the game for me and literally guaranteed a bad ending for me as early as chapter 2 (of 5).
Here are the questions, verbatim:
Emily: how about you after college, do you want to settle down like right after?
(my answer: no)
Evelyn: what are your plans after college, do you want a family?
(my answer: yes)
As you can see, Emily specifically asked about RIGHT after college, where as Evelyn asked about after college in general. I tried to answer both as honestly as possible. My personal plans are to start a family but not until 10 yrs or so after school.
I liked the first Emily is Away game because it showed a realistic rendition of how people drift apart. It was heartbreaking, but so so real.
However the reactions of the characters in this story are not realistic at all.
**spoilers below**
[spoiler]
I ended up dating Emily, and it was going really well, I felt endearment to both characters on a deep level and I was enjoying the experience. Then in chapter 5 Evelyn tells Emily that I wanted a family, and Emily thought I didn't. Emily sees this as me flat-out lying and suddenly doesn't trust anything I ever said, and said I manipulated both her and Evelyn. I am never truly given a chance to explain myself, I have to say I lied to Evelyn to try to damage control. The game makes it seem for a moment that I could possibly fix this mess, but no I can't.
It felt like a super videogamey moment, like I gave the "wrong" answer in a silly quiz that happened at the beginning of the game. Like yeah, I can replay the game, but what's the point? It won't feel as meaningful and I'll just have to reread a shitton of text just to change one answer of one question in one chapter.
[/spoiler]
Anyway, it's a really good game with mostly good writing and ideas. Most people will have a good experience with it, I think. Just that one moment could easily be fixed by removing the word "right".

39260674.review:
Emily is Away Too is a direct upgrade graphically and mechanically from it's first title of the series.
The concept is still the same. a text adventure choices-matters narrative set up on the ol' chat services from the 00's
The game now takes most of your answers in consideration. Unlocking special dialogs and paths. 
While this is great, the only 3 available options could be translated onto " Strongly Agree, Doubt, Disagree". Wich may end up feeling as if the main character (you) didn't had any bias towards any outcome. Wich is great, but most of the time you'll be only responding to actual events, unlike EIA 1. You'll eventually feel the game extremely linear despite the choices you could take. The addition of downloads and the time attacks is extremely appreciated.

The story is... okay at best. No tension, textbook drama and overall the game highlights the best outcome due to it's poor writing. While it encourages players to replay and choose different outcomes, it really lacks the motivation to do so. Emily is now extremely bland, even in the best case scenario you won't feel any kind of attachments. Main Character is now way more confident on it's answers, at first it struggles to express himself but he can end up being a prick to both girls wich just creates a narrative dissonance breaking all inmersion.

Why do I still recommend this game? Because it's absolutely beautiful, and absolutely worth the price. It will also provide you with nice backgrounds, icons and nostalgic trips to your favourite websites.

if you did not like EIA or if you never used a chat service back in the days, you won't like EIA2.

Nice references, tho.

39245171.review:
An interesting concept. For anyone who enjoyed the heady days of AOL Instant Messenger, or MSN Messenger, this will probably bring back some fascinating memories. The mechanisms working behind your decisions are very obvious and basic, but there are many hidden gems of humour hidden away if you can find them, and I suspect there is something in there for everyone.

The game is all over after a couple of hours, and achievements are very easy, with Rick Rolled being the only one that is a little harder to get unless you click on everything, or seek help from others.

39242546.review:
Emily ha vuelto, y se ha traído a más gente. "Emily is away 2" plantea la misma dinámica que en la primera entrega, pero a principios del 2000: sigue siendo una ventana de chat donde podremos conversar, en esta ocasión con Emily y Evelyn. Al igual que en el anterior, la conversación (y la opinión que tienen de nosotros) se irá construyendo en función de las respuestas y comentarios que vayamos seleccionando entre las opciones que nos presenta el juego. 

La sencilla mecánica de tener que escribir cada letra de la frase que envías sigue funcionando como mecanismo de inmersión, especialmente para los viejunos que vivimos aquella época. Un añadido muy interesante es la posibilidad de intercambiar enlaces con nuestras amigas, que nos llevan a páginas de facelook o de youtoob diseñadas para el juego y que nos permitirán ampliar la jugabilidad para conocer a nuestras amigas más allá de la ventana de chat. Otra variante de la jugabilidad más puntual es el de responder en un tiempo determinado para evitar que dejen de hablarnos, buscando hacerlo más difícil aprovechando que esta vez hablamos con dos personajes, pero para mi gusto le resta bastante inmersión al convertir la conversación más en una carrera que en algo significativo, donde eliges con cuidado lo que contestas para provocar la reacción adecuada.

"Emily is away 2" no es tan fresco como el primero, pero es un digno sucesor y amplía algunas opciones que le dan un punto extra. Vale la pena jugarlo.

39161620.review:
This is a truly excellent game. Much improved upon the first in every way. I found the story was more coherent and believeable, and in the inclusion of choice was much appreciated. The characters are written very realistically, and the UI is very representative of those old school IM clients. By the end of my first playthrough (which wasn't the best ending), I was legitimately questioning my own behavior as I was so invested in the story being told. Despite this being very obviously scripted and artificial, it didn't feel that way at all.

My only real complaint is that the logic kind of falls apart in the end, depending on how you played through the game. I hope that, in a future sequel, the creators add more nuance to the scripts so that small errors can be dealt with in a more realistic manner. Otherwise, I am very impressed. Highly recommended!

39034196.review:
A great and fairly accurate look into the mid-to-late 2000s teen culture and romance, expressed entirely through an AIM-like messenger window. This game is more subjective than others as it is a story with only your words as the interaction, and sometimes it'll hit you in the feels if you grew up in that era like I did - maybe you'll hear an old song from high school and you'll be right back at the family computer chatting with your crush from 3rd period, trying to dance around what you really want to say until all the pieces fall right where they're supposed to.
Definitely recommended for those who want a glimpse of what it was like, or those who want to revisit those careless days.

38991030.review:
Read this review, it is a true life story:

This game did nothing but opening my wounds from 11 years ago when I was 15. They say Christmas is time for magic and miracle and guess what, by accident Humble Bundle made a mistake with my account and made an unwanted purchase with my wallet I went to the website and see what game was bought by mistake and I saw this was it. And this is where a night of my life turned to tears:

What I am writing here is based on a true life story, 11 years ago in 2006 it was my first online game experience on GameSpy Arcade and I met someone that I had no idea she was a girl. We were talking for a while then when she gave me her MSN (If you are old enough you know what that is) I saw the photo I asked her if she is a girl she laughed and she said yes. I asked her name and it was "Emily".

After 3 months just talking on the internet one day she asked about my music taste and we had a very different music taste. But it was interesting for her (exactly like how it goes in this game). I was living in Iran by the time and she was from England. We had no way of seeing each other so all we could do was just to chat. She talked about her video games she liked Sims and Crash and I liked shooters and strategies. It truly was a shock for me but in this game one of the profile pictures you can take is "Company of Heroes" which was the game I was playing day and night back in 2006.

She spent a lot of time training my English and she was very successful. After a while I really started to feel for her although it was only internet. It even got to a point that I was dreaming that I was meeting her in person. She was very keeping in showing her emotions she was a very strong girl and very grown up in behaviour. We kept our connection for 7 years but it had up and downs.

In March 2014 we got in to a very bad argue over internet because of college she had moved to Germany and I was doing my best to go there I even learnt German but embassy rejected me just cause I was born in Iran although I even passed the German test which again was thanks to her help over internet teaching me German cause she was studying it. She started to be realistic saying this is going no where and we will never meet. I did not want to accept that I pushed it way too much that it really got scary for her and she ended all the connection ways by blocking me. I was very upset I had a pain in my heart that I really can't describe. I never had this feeling for any girl before although I had met them in person and not internet but I never ever did feel any pain like that night.

It took me a week to get over it. I started my swimming classes and I completely forgot about all of it. I am not sure how many of you played this game through "Emily" side but me and her had a nickname for each other and the nickname I chose for her 10 years ago does exist in this game with a little bit of difference. I was calling her "Mimily" and she was calling me Prince of Persia.

4 months ago I came to Poland because for some reason I ended up being accepted to work for a video game company here in charge of MK X and Injustice for PC and many other games. One night I was walking in one of the streets in Warsaw and I saw this big hotel called "Marriott" which was Emily's surname. Believe me or not go to google and search it yourself, this hotel is located in a street called "Emili" and right on the other side of this hotel there is a small restaurant called "Prince of Persia". Can you imagine the feeling I had that night?

I dated many girls in these 4 years but none was something I could feel in my heart like I did with her. Every time I was reading a chat line in this video game it was like a sparkle of my past coming back to me. I feel like it was made for me, I have no idea how this is possible but if this is not miracle then what is it? Signs?

Thank you all for reading this, maybe I wrote too much off topic but I hope you understand how this game effected me and made me to type all these lines here.

38963023.review:
I really want to recommend this game. It does a great job of evoking that universal sense of overly-emotional teenage angst and stirring up nostalgia for early-mid '00s internet life. Unfortunately, the game's potential for telling an impactful story is sabotaged by overly simple dialog logic trees that eventually railroad you into a confrontation that makes no sense and ultimately ruins the immersion.

The first (and more forgivable) of the two major offenses were the Chapter 3 conversations that continuously speed up until it becomes physically impossible to maintain a conversation with both characters in a satisfactory amount of time. In my case, my conversation with Evelyn derailed with her saying [spoiler]"i was so mad, i punched him and just started yelling at him"[/spoiler] and following up with [spoiler]"what the fuck? are you even listening?"[/spoiler] literally THREE SECONDS LATER. Even for characters that are supposed to be young (17? 18?) and easily upset, no reasonable person would flip out and shut down over a delay this short, even during an important conversation. 

The decision to format the game this way, even as a fork-in-the-road means of forcing you to choose how you focus time on one character, is sloppily done from a gameplay standpoint and totally egregious from a storytelling perspective; outside of someone with diagnosed, untreated manic issues, which Evelyn is never hinted to have, no real person would react this way. It totally ruins the moment.

The major experience-ruining story issue occurs in the last chapter. In my case, the game took an offhand, one-sentence comment I made -- something that many people could plausibly say in casual conversation, and could easily change their mind about later -- and threw it back in my face as a colossal "lie." (It's seriously something minor; not a lie, not even something intentionally misleading. Something many people would consider an opinion more than a declaration of intent.) The other characters react to it (again, something completely innocuous that could EASILY be explained away) as though they had caught me at the scene of a murder with a smoking gun in my hand. The game seems to provide you with an opportunity to explain yourself after this confrontation, but all the dialogue options are a bunch of feckless, directionless word salad that get you no closer to any obvious explanations or reassurances.

Honestly, the most frustrating part about it to me was that I went out of my way to be honest with the other characters throughout the entire game, yet had it torpedoed two hours later over a total misunderstanding. I don't know whether to describe it as the fruitless product of writer's block or just plain laziness, but the clumsy ending to the story over a completely unrealistic interaction between characters ruined the entire experience for me.

With some fine-tuning to the interactions and script, this could be a highly recommended experience. As it is, it's more liable to frustrate than engage.

I really enjoyed revisiting YTMND's heyday, though.

38920754.review:
[h1][b]Soy un @#$% masoquista[/b][/h1]

[b]No sé en qué estaba pensando cuando se me cruzó por la cabeza el pensamiento de que [i]Emily Is Away Too[/i] podría renovar su fórmula y adoptarla a una historia que realmente no se sienta como un conflicto de adolescentes que ya por hablar y ser del sexo contrario tienen que plantearse el hecho de ser pareja de la forma más deplorable y mediocre posible. 

No se puede representar con ningún símbolo matemático lo equivocado que estaba.[/b]

[h1]Argumento paupérrimo[/h1]
Creo que con que leáis [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/iGunzerkeR/recommended/417860/] mi análisis de Emily Is Away [/url] me ahorro de volver a explicar la estructura principal que envuelve a la saga.

Si en la primera entrega contábamos solo con la intervención de Emily y el resultado ya era catastrófico de por sí, en este juego duplicamos la tragedia debido a la introducción de otra chica más al asunto, Evelyn. Esto también implica que el tiempo de juego aumente y, por tanto, el sufrimiento sea mayor.

Todo sigue la misma línea, con los mismos diálogos tipo "oh qué alegre soy de que seas mi amiga, ¡seamos más que amigos! te quiero tanto <3", sin olvidarnos también del gran giro argumental y la gran evolución personal de las chavalas, teniendo conversaciones como "uf mi novio me está manipulando, me trata mal y no me siento bien con él. Pero oh, qué bien me siento hablando contigo Mike eres mi persona favorita, ¡qué bien que seamos amigos! ^^". 

Los varios desenlaces del último capítulo son lo más "por la cara" que he visto en mucho tiempo, sin ningún tipo de manipulación por parte del equipo de desarrollo ni tampoco por parte de nuestro personaje (ejem). 

Sin duda, una referencia de la que debería aprender TODA la industria del videojuego.

[h1]Puntos positivos (porque también los tiene, o eso creo)[/h1]
Una novedad implementada respecto a su antecesor es una especie de red de Internet que se crea con el fin de emular redes sociales tales como YouTube o Facebook, las cuales me sorprendieron para bien debido a la cantidad de detalles que se incluyen en estas. 

Se hará uso de este recurso para detalles menores, como mirar los perfiles de tus amigos (3 ó 4) y vídeos musicales que Evelyn y Emily enviarán. Sin duda, bastante llamativo y curioso.

Otro punto que me gustó fue el hecho de que se pongan vínculos en el escritorio cuando las chicas dicen que nos van a enviar un archivo, como una foto o una conversación. Otro detalle más anecdótico que se usa un par de veces, y ya.

[h1]Conclusión[/h1]
Este título es una pérdida de tiempo, no lo podría describir de otra forma. Si os gustó la primera entrega, esta sigue la misma línea e incluso puede que os guste más por la inclusión de un segundo personaje con el que interactuar. Sin embargo, si os gustó 0 la primera, este os parecerá infernal, por lo que ya os adelanto de que no vais a notar ni un solo cambio a nivel argumental.

No vale mi tiempo ni los 0,50€ que me ha costado.

38919800.review:
The game offers a really fun and unique experience. It did actually take me back to the days of instant message chats, talking for hours with people I cared about, discussing intimate topics and building friendships and relationships, while listening to the music  you liked and the new stuff your friends suggested. I've never quite had that feeling of being close to people on the internet after these messaging chats died out.

The game isn't very long, you can rush it in 2 hours, but you'd probably want to take your time exploring "facenook" pages, "youtoob" videos and such. At first the information about your chat friends seems excessive, but coming back to someone's facenook page to carefully read the info mid game feels really nice. The conversations, emotions and stories are well-written, you easily believe a teenager would think and react like that - just remember yourself at that age.

There are multiple endings, not all of which are different enough to warrant a new playthrough, but you'd definitely want to replay the game a couple of times. Myself, I had a lot of fun finishing the game 3 times back to back, the last one of which I put the actual music I liked listening to back in the day. Very nostalgic, highly recommend.

38908463.review:
Emily Is Away Too is the "sequel" or perhaps the more polished version of the original typing simulator Emily Is Away. I remember playing it a long while ago and thinking a lot about it. When I saw a close friend gush about how good Emily Is Away Too is, I decided to pick it up on sale with some Steam funds, and I thoroughly do not regret it.

[h1]STORY: 10/10[/h1]
In Emily Is Away Too, you play as a friend of the characters Emily and Evelyn, two characters who you chat with over the fictional EOL service. You're all teenagers rounding off high school in senior year. And just like we all experience in high school, whether or not senior year, there's themes of depression, anxiety, relationships, changing interests, what to even do with life after high school. As somebody in high school right now, this hits right on home. And boy, this game reels you in and when you slip up and mix up one name, it scolds you. It makes you feel hurt because you were paying more attention to Evelyn than Emily. And it stings, because you know how that feels to try and balance two friendships. It hurt when I first messed up. It hurt so bad that I logged out of the game and closed it, to come back to it in a couple hours after playing something a bit lighter. This game is all the pain of high school in one small chat client.

[h1]GRAPHICS: 7/10[/h1]
Seriously, I can't expect much for a pixelated game in a chat client. It's basic. Maybe this means I should get rid of this category, because it generally means nothing. It's not like you can't see anything, so I think it's pretty good.

[h1]GAMEPLAY: 8/10[/h1]
Emily Is Away Too is a typing simulator. You choose your icon, you set up your description, and you choose from up to 3 messages to send to Emily or Evelyn. These texts determine your relationships with these characters, and, as stated above, can make or break those relationships. [spoiler]For example, I had a GREAT relationship with Emily, so great that I would call her "Em" instead. When I mistakenly replied to her relationship problems using the name "Steve" as her boyfriend instead of his actual name, she was very upset.[/spoiler] Sometimes Emily and Evelyn will send you links to fictional websites, which open in your actual browser, and are knockoffs of websites we use daily like Youtube and Google and Facebook. You can listen to music on these sites, send friend requests, and click around.

[h1](RE)PLAYABILITY: 10/10[/h1]
There are so many routes you can go. With the emotional attachment you get to Evelyn and Emily, I'm hoping you choose the ones with the best outcomes. You can say "deuces" or "howdy" or "that sucks" or "**** that guy!". The choice is in your hands. Will you make Emily and Evelyn happy? Or will your relationships slowly fall apart as you drift away from one, the other, or both?

[h1]OVERALL: 9/10[/h1]
Emily Is Away Too is a great game. Emily Is Away Too is an amazing game. It's not just a text simulator, it's reliving the memories from friends in high school simulator. It sucks you in and tears you apart. If you're looking for a lighthearted jaunt with Emily, you're not going to get it here. Buy this game. Buy this game if you want to feel truly hurt for messing up. Buy this game if you're also bad at making quick decisions. Buy this game.

Смешанные впечатления по поводу игры.
С одной стороны почти то же самое, что и первая игра, но с небольшими нововведениями, другими персонажами и наличием счастливых концовок. С другой, то ли именно дело в наличии этих самых счастливых концовок, то ли в том, что персонажи недостаточно прописаны, впечатление от этой игрушки не такое сильное, как от оригинала. Самый жирный минус игры - взаимозаменяемость персонажей. Несмотря на то, что у них вроде как разные характеры и образы жизни, у них почти одинаковые истории, а после середины игры разница между ними полностью стирается. Я прошёл 2 сценария, и очевидно, что они сделаны лишь для галочки, т.к. между ними почти нет никакой разницы за исключением незначительных деталей. Вот за этот единственный на мой взгляд минус я не знаю, стоит ли эту игру рекомендовать. По скидке думаю можно взять, всё-таки тут есть прикольные моменты.

38895762.review:
To start off, this game is a fucking masterpiece. Zero doubt about that. It gives light to a very overshadowed period of time, the early 2000's. Holy goddamn is it easy for this game to draw you in, far better than any AAA title recently, and these two characters dont even have faces. Oh did I mention that this game has 3 major characters? THREE!! A Text Adventure has somehow become my game of the year. Who knew. 

On a more serious note, this game is incredibly written, so much so that it manages to convey two important lessons in a subject matter that, lets be honest, a large margin of the gaming community is well versed in. Romance. Those lessons are 1. How to move on (somwhat carried over from the first game) and 2. That transition and realationships do not mix, and that in reality it is usually worth it to just shake hands and go your separate ways, instead of plugging holes in a sinking ship. even if it is a very new, fancy ship you worked very hard for. 
Now obviously the second lesson is a little meatier, so I'll start there. In the game, your character is wrapping up their highschool career. This is vital to the story, we will come back to it. You start AIMing with two girls, Evanlyn and Emily. The latter more bookish, while the prior is more of a teenage punkier sort of charcter. As you build your friendship and overall relationship with both, you will hopefully seduce one blah blah blah you know the rest. Drama and difficult sacrafices ensue. (None of which are very unrealistic whatsoever). However, if you play the game with that positive twist, and hopefully end up dating one of them, the positive endings are just, meh. Unsatisfying. Whimsical. Fluffy. And then if youre anything like me you play again with a negative twist and find that the end where you leave them behind and go into college a fresh start, is much more satisfying as a story arc. It sucks, and feels like a real punch in the gut, but it is the truth.

That is the amazing thing about this game. It is written so well, that people without a face and unstable identities (they are indeed very much teenagers) can make you feel such intese emotion, and really sear these lessons into your mind. Using nothing but good writing, and incredibly outdated technology. 

10/10 IGN

It's difficult to talk about this game without spoiling parts of it, but I can say that those who were teenagers and figuring out who they were in an era where AIM was the main form of online communication and platforms like Myspace, Facebook, and YouTube were first coming into their own will almost instantly connect with Emily is Away Too.

It's a short game, but a branching narrative gives plenty of incentive to play again. I'm planning to give it a few more runs, having just finished my first one. This game perfectly captures the feeling of stumbling face first into the world of relationships, deep friendship, and gossip while being wholly unprepared to deal with it. It's almost too perfect an encapsulation for those of us who were in high school in the mid-2000s.

I've never played anything quite like this game before, and I'm happy I came across it and gave it a chance. It provided a gameplay experience I'm not going to forget for some time to come.

38835020.review:
This game is sort of difficult to compare to other games i've played. It had me extremely invested, and brought back some memories from the past that in some cases I'd rather forget. Throughout I felt like i really was talking to these people. It al felt real. Like soemthing that could very much happen.

You struggle between the friendship of two potential love interests. The game relies on this and makes the price of it worth it compared to it's free predecessor, as well as an overall longer playtime (though not by much).

As this was written the game had taken me about 2 hours to complete. It shows you how little mistakes and accidents (like telling a semi-different story to one than the other, or not answering a message in time) can really affect the story as far as I can tell. The game has multiple outcomes and options, giving it a much better replay value than the first game did, and I found myself to be much more into the game this time around as well.

I felt love and joy within this story, I found confusion and anger, i found sadness and emptiness. and while these can't always be helped, I found this game had a pace that felt all too real. Yeah, you meant well but it can lead to bad outcomes. This feeling of regret knowing what you could have done better is incredible, and like i said: real. You get those "oh no" feelings, and when you do something right (like possibly getting together with one of the characters), it feels really good. 

I would reccomend this to just about everyone, and while it didn't give me a new perspective on life or anything like that, It left me with a sort of "shook" feeling. How you just gotta deal with these actions and try to work out all of this. 
I'd probably buy it full price, but if you arent sure, play the first game, then come back for an even better experience. If it is on sale, but it now. It's worth every cent for less than five bucks. Go for it and enjoy itttt.

38824004.review:
I quite enjoyed the original Emily is Away when I played it years ago. It delivered a painfully plausible experience, a realistic (if distilled) depiction of what it’s like to slowly drift away from someone you used to be close to. Central to that experience was the inevitability of the singular ending, and the way the game slowly takes away player agency as you approach it.

Emily is Away Too has none of those things. Plausible and realistic are not words I would use to describe it at all.

Emily is Away Too gives you the option to converse with two girls this time rather than one, but only covers senior year. Rather than covering the tearful goodbyes that typically punctuate one’s final year of highschool or re-delivering on that feeling of separation, however, Emily is Away Too instead tells the story of a cheap highschool drama, the kind you could likely find in teen novels anywhere. If the game’s goal was to make you feel frustrated with the idiocy of teenagers, then it succeeded. If it was going for anything else, it failed miserably.

Emily is Away Too also feels distinctly gamey and unrealistic in your conversations with the two girls. In a few points during the short narrative there are time limits on how quickly you need to reply to one or both of the girls. Conceptually, this is fine, as it adds a layer of urgency to the game. In practice, it’s frustrating; sometimes you have as little as a few seconds to choose and type your reply, when in real life I’ve sometimes taken minutes to carefully consider what I want to say in a serious conversation. I’ve never had anyone respond as vitriolically to my delays as the girls do here; in fact, I’ve never had anyone complain at all. There’s also the fact that a single contradiction at the beginning of the game can ultimately net you a “bad end” with one of the girls calling your entire relationship fake and a lie. More frustrating is the fact that this “contradiction” might not even be a contradiction at all. In my case, I told one girl I could maybe see myself having kids in the future, and told another I could maybe see myself not having kids. Both are true (as I don't know what I want with regards to children yet), and I didn’t lie to either girl, but the game gave me no chance to offer this explanation, and I was called an intentional manipulator and liar. Like I said, if the game’s goal was to make you feel frustrated with the idiocy of teenagers, then it succeeded. If it was going for anything else, it failed miserably.

Ultimately, this game failed to deliver a unique experience or one as poignant and painfully plausible as the first game did. Rather than paying for the inferior Emily is Away Too, you’re better off simply replaying the better original for free.

Unlike the first one, this one costs money, so I'm judging it as an actual game.

And . . . it sadly doesn't work how I'd want it to. While the story is very cool and interesting, it just didn't hold my interest as much as other ones. It just felt incomplete.

From what I can tell, there are 2 endings, [spoiler] one where you choose Emily and other where you choose Evelyn. [/spoiler] It made me feel like none of my actions held weight, cause it would come down to 2 happy outcomes. If there was a chance of getting a bad ending, I didn't see it. I tried being the meanest person I could, and it still ended in me being with someone. I'm not saying all games need to end badly, but it felt like the creator got too many complaints about the first ones unhappy ending and decided to remove it.

One thing I DID enjoy were the secret codes. They would allow you to see secret profiles and even talk to them. And there were a lot: Youtubers, TV shows, other games. I didn't get them all simply because I haven't seen/played the material, but the ones I did get were hilarious to read.

I also liked the fake website idea, where they linked to YouToob videos or Facenook pages. It was funny to see the blocky imitations of websites.

All in all, I didn't really like this one as opposed to the first one. Mostly because I paid to see this story. I don't really want to say "Don't get it", but I think I'm gonna have to on this one. Sorry.

38692235.review:
This is not the greatest game I have played.  It did not cause me to become overly emotional.  It is inspiring me, however, to write my first steam review.

I felt that the original was lacking a little substance, and this one improved on it in some surprising ways.  The dialogue was substantial enough that I was able to grow attached to the characters, and one character in particular.  The interactions outside the chatbox were interesting and definitely true to life; the "youtoob" music served as an excellent backdrop for teenage melodrama.

After a while, I began to feel that I was role-playing myself at 17.  This game unearthed some interesting thoughts and emotions that I had thought long dead.  It was fun, for a while, to revisit that place.  It's not often that a videogame reaches deep inside of a person like this, and while I would never want to go back and live my confusing teenage years again, it was really special to be reminded of who I was, and some of the steps I took to get here.

For anyone, and especially for someone who enjoys games as experiences, and appreciates when they try to work outside your expectations, I would highly, highly recommend this game.

38687536.review: The first Emily is Away was a great little free game that illustrated the harsh realities that come with people growing apart. Wasn't a particularly "feel good" experience but It was convincing enough for what it was trying to accomplish. Gives a good lession about how important it is to be transparant and remain true to who you are as a person. A very rewarding experience.

I loved the original Emily is Away, and this second iteration on the formula certainly does not disappoint. It's a pretty accurate portrayal of a slice of life experienced by many: the complex sociality of IM-based relationship building, with all its imperfections and ambiguities. The writing is clever, and though you can end up in frustrating situations, they're all based on character traits and flaws that are extremely realistic, so it never seems unfair. I went through a couple of playthroughs, and I'm curious to explore more branches still. It's also a pleasant trip down memory lane, with the music and the cultural references that are, in my opinion, very on point.

If the premise sounds interesting to you, I think it's pretty safe to say you will like this game.

38641012.review:
This game is as it looks, it's set up like a retro instant messaging program. Heck, you can even have this game running while playing something else and you'll feel like your actually talking to someone while doing other things on the computer. Great for if you don't have any real life friends.

The game has two paths, you can choose to get close with Emily or Evelyn. Choices you make dictate how much they like you and so on down the path. The game gives you three options to choose from as responses to things the girls ask or say, and you can mash your keyboard as the game types it out for you. The game isn't really hard since if you are just honest and polite you can beat it. My first play through I got a good ending with Emily and I honestly wasn't even trying, I was just being lazy. Not saying the game is bad by any means for being easy for people with souls, but it's nice to play a game where the plot twist isn't a "Screw you for being a nice guy". 

You can also customize your profile pic as well to add a little customization to your life. Some are memes, some are video game logos, and others are band logos. Speaking of bands, I hope you like indie music, because this game is going to throw so much indie youtube link songs your way. Every starting conversation with either girl always starts with "listen to this song."

I would recommend as it is a nice time killer game. My only grief is that I'm way out of my high school years in age, and playing this game thats about talking to girls in high school made me feel dirty. Some of my responses to their personal problems they had made me come across as a fatherly figure, yet in the end, Emily said she loved me and wanted to cuddle and stay with me forever. Kids now days.

38638825.review:
Incredibly accurate recreation of 2006 chatting, I closed all tabs except what the game gave me and felt like I'd fallen through a time portal. It's commendable how well this is executed, even down to the retro youtube pages. The dialogue is snappy and lifelike, and there's usually a response close to exactly what I wanted to say. Usually...

The one point of critique I have comes at the end, where there's a bit of a gotcha moment for drama. It's very easy to have a misunderstanding, without any options to explain or add nuance. Make sure your messages are completely consistent if you want a good ending.

The ending soured the game for me a little, but that's my one knock on it. If you're a millennial and want to feel nostalgia for a decade ago, definitely give this game a try.

38637498.review:
TL;DR: This game is pretty good, but it's not without its issues. If you have 5 bucks to spare, and you are someone who does multiple playthroughs of a game to get multiple endings, I'd reccomend it. (SPOILERS AHEAD)

Let me start by saying the general aesthetic of the game, its sound effects, the background noise, the clicks of the computer that are in game, are well done and really help to make you feel like you are on a computer from 2006. This game does style very nicely and I liked the touch of giving you a desktop background to choose from, as well as the many fake old websites such as YouToob.

As far as characters go, everything is pretty believable and seems real up until a bit of chapter 3 and (if you got the ending I got) chapter 5. In chapter 3 there is a mechanic that you have to reply to a girl in about 5 seconds, or they get really upset with you. This kinda felt weird because in reality if you dont reply to someone in 5 seconds they're not gonna freak out and say fuck you and go offline. Although I do understand why it was done and I do think it added a semi-fun mechanic, it was still a bit weird. Chapter 5 had a major issue if you picked a specific couple of answers, but I'll get to that next.

Now, for my major issue with the game. As you're playing you'll quickly realize one of the main mechanics is about not lying about what your character does. As I played through this game I built up who my character was in my head and what he has done, and for the most part this game allows you to do that... except in two cases (that I've found.) One of them is about being a virgin or not. Now, I decided that my character has only ever gotten to third base with someone, so when Eve asked me if I've had sex in the past, I picked "Well kinda.." (or whatever option was closest to that.) The game then autocorrected that to "Yes," even though I did not pick that option. I later told Emily what I thought my actual character did, which was getting to third base.

The second choice that was weird was about having kids. I told Eve that I would like to have kids in the future and settle down, but I also told Emily that I can respect her viewpoint in life of not wanting to settle down right away, as I'm not sure anyone would be 100% sure to do that, and because so much can change over time. I never specifically told her I did not want to have kids.

In chapter 5 Eve tells Emily that I wanted to have kids and that I was not a virgin when talking to her. This is weird in multiple ways. Why was Eve telling my girlfriend about personal stuff like that, and why were they discussing everything I've said like I'm in court or something? The OTHER problem is, when Emily eventually messaged me to say "Fuck you liar," I really didn't KNOW what I had lied about. And that's when it hit me (mostly because the game told me.) Because of the way the game dances around the kids question with Emily, and because of the fact the game DELETED one of my answers and put in another one, it robbed me of a good ending that I spent 2 hours trying to get. I did end up playing again, going for Eve, and getting a good ending but I really should've gotten that ending from the start.

That brings me to my next point, which is should you buy this game?  I usually look at games at a 1$ = 1hr rule. If I am spending 5 dollars on a game, I should get 5 hours of enjoyment. If I am spending 40, I should get 40 hours. I got this game on sale for 2.49$, and with that, my first playthrough was 2.7 hours, meaning I got my money's worth. But, even with a second playthrough, I still only have 4.1 hours in the game. So, if you're planning on playing through this game only once, you should wait for a sale.

Overall even with it's problems I'd give this game a 7/10. If the kids issue is made more clear to choose and if the game is patched to NOT correct the "well kinda" answer into "yes," then it would be 8.5/10. Overall a pretty solid experience.

38593521.review:
I write this review with a very heavy heart.
Emily is Away was one of my favorite games I've played in the past year or so. The story was unique and compelling, and brought an amazing sense of nostalgia and realism to playing the game that reflects highschool and college relationships in a brutally realistic way. The first game explored a relationship between the player and Emily, and their transition from highschool to college life and the reality of growing apart. No matter what choices you made or how you played the game, the player and Emily were going to grow apart. This was a major reflection on the situation that a lot of kids feel as they grow up. People grow apart and sometimes fairytale endings just don't exist no matter what you do to try and get one. It was a gorgeous story of adolescence and heartbreak, portrayed through the conversations of two teenagers over the nostalgic aol messanger.
Coming from the first game, I was so excited for Emily is Away 2. I was excited to explore the relationship of these two characters before they split and why it was so heartbreaking for the player to lose her in the first game. I was ready to have my already crushed heart burned and run over. But this game was absolutely not what I was waiting for. I bought this game soon after it came out, a tissue box by my side. However, what I got was a dating sim. Now some people may enjoy that type of game, Emily is Away was so much more. The characters were deep and complex and somehow the decisions you made never seemed to work out in the end, speaking on the true reality of highschool friendships. This entire theme and complexity was invalidated by this game. A new character is introduced as a romance option, and you can choose to flirt with her or Emily. Where the original game was meaningful and heartbreaking, this game was shallow and lost all meaning by turning Emily into a stereotypical highschool girl that could be swayed by a kind word. This is not the truth of the world. The first game was so successful because of the inevitable truth that it portrayed. That truth is lost in this game. I wish I had never bought it, as all of the beauty of the first game was washed away by this superficial dating  sim.

Около 2 лет назад на Gamejolt нашел оригинальную версию этой игры, если не изменяет память, там был лишь один персонаж, Эмили, и все повествование строилось только вокруг нее. Здесь же получилась гораздо более расширенная версия той самой игры с переделанным сюжетом и новыми фишками, они не сильно изменили геймплей (практически не изменили), но тем не менее приятно разнообразили игровой процесс.
Оригинал я прошел несколько раз, пытался получить разные концовки, но то ли так и было задумано, то ли я криворукий, но итог был всегда плачевный. Здесь же заявлены несколько концовок, игру пока прошел один раз, концовку получил именно такую, какая указана прямо в названии игры.
Из геймлпейных новшеств, помимо посещения разных сайтов и скачивания файлов, я могу лишь отметить так называемые ответы на время, благодаря им же, как я и понял, делаются важнейшие выборы в игре. А так все практически не изменилось, но это и не плохо, скорее наоборот. Есть еще какой-то Emily Online, но пока не проверял что это.
По прохождению: игра не успевает надоесть, она ни коротка, ни затянута, но лично меня она не заставила как-то проникнуться историями персонажей, не знаю, но хотя в конце улыбался, а потом расстроился.
В общем, в любом случае я доволен игрой, не думал, что у оригинала будет продолжение, и оно вышло хорошим, я считаю. Попробую перепройти еще раз, посмотреть насколько разнообразны концовки в игре.

38430740.review:
Like its free predecessor, it creates an impactful and meaningful story in the form of an IM messenger. Only this time, there is another person besides Emily that you can talk to, called Evelyn. The game offers more variety in terms of choices this time around, and your choices WILL matter. It will change the path of the story. Choose carefully.

The game is chalk full of nostalgia and easter eggs, so you have to keep a lookout for those. The game also sends actual links to you and puts files on your actual desktop, so be sure to open them. They're full of nostalgia, information, and funny stuff. I thought it was a really cool concept in the previous game, and they've only took it even further.

The writing of this game is also quite good. The "teenage" speech is cringy, but at the same time nostalgic. The conversations actually do touch on many teenage subjects and some important topics, life lessons, and themes. I found myself immersed and it brought me back to my elementary and teenage years. It was an awesome experience to be engrossed in for around 3 hours.

Great game, and there is definitely replayability if you wish to explore both Emily and Evelyn's route. But for me, best girl Evelyn is enough. Deuces. ;)

38410798.review:
虽然打了差评，但是说在前头，这游戏本身有着还算是令人满意的素质，我认为是值得各位一试的作品。然而Steam的推荐/不推荐机制从来不要求玩家按照完全客观的标准去打分，而我既不是Gamespot也不是QGN，[b]我认为我有权利在购买了游戏使用权却在被内容深深屎到之后，[/b]饱含愤慨地，或者说无能狂怒地打出我“不推荐”的差评。

而我被屎到的过程大致如下。

采用了和一代相似的游戏系统，本作依然是以聊天软件对话的形式推进剧情。不过相比一代的单攻略对象Emily，本作新加入了角色Evelyn，这个女孩子比起Emily更为开放和活泼，且在游戏初期就明显表现出对主角的热情。游戏的第一章和第二章在Emily与Evelyn的交替对话中进行，虽然我个人不是很喜欢[spoiler]或者说很反感[/spoiler]主角这种对一个女孩心有所属的同时又对其他女孩子说“I am always here”之类暧昧不清的言辞，但是前两章的节奏整体还是可以接受的。

[h1]屎到我的地方是游戏的第三章。[/h1]

在这一章里，两个女孩子都会第一时间主动找你聊天，我本以为桃花运今天砸到我头上了，还没开心一毫秒，就发现这两个妹子似乎都有感情相关的非常非常重要的苦恼要只对我一人倾诉。我一开始自然是选择了全部倾听，哪怕我不想泡这个妹子，在一个女孩子脆弱的时候也不好拒绝。[spoiler]最重要的是我™也根本没看到拒绝的选项[/spoiler] 然而对话到一半，我发现对话框上方出现了时间条，并且又发现只要时间条消耗光，该对话框的妹子就会“Are you still here？”我当然™一直在这里，但是这狗屎的时间条越走越快，我怎么能在短短几秒里看完对话选好回复然后疯狂脸滚键盘打字？在对话后期，我不得不快速TAB切换外加疯狂打字，然而试了好几遍都无法把两个人的对话都好好听完，总有一条时间条会走光，然后其中一个女孩子伤心离去。

后来我查了一些攻略和资料，感觉这里应该是必然的二选一。而且这是影响最终结局的最关键一章，玩家在此必须鸽掉其中一个妹子。

我真是被这™的智障设定惊到了。

上面我就提到了，我一开始就对主角和两个女孩子暧昧不清的设定有点不爽。如果说之前只是把其中一个当做非常非常close的朋友，那么第三章怎么解释？稍微设身处地想一下这个情景：有两个妹子同时和你发信息，你发现她们心情都特别差，而且是由于一些非常私密的爱情问题。她们要向你倾诉了，而你明确地意识到，听她们倾诉完这种事情，你和对方的关系就会迈向more than friends。意识到这一切的你，决定只好忍痛割爱，只好好对待自己喜欢的女孩子，不得不对另一个道歉，说“我现在不行，抱歉。”

然后，你™天杀的发现这游戏没有“I am sorry”的选项。

是的，在第三章里，当两个妹子在非常悲伤的处境下要对你倾诉时，你只能选择“I am here”之类的回复，导致两个妹子都觉得你是值得依赖的。而在妹子开始倾诉后，天杀的时间条就会像被续了一样飞快地流逝，流逝到你发现你必须放弃其中一个，不然两个人都会被你惹怒。放弃一次已经够恶心了，然而当你和你选择的那个女孩聊到2/3，对话会再次卡住。是的，你必须去和你鸽了的那个妹子解释，但是™天杀的是，这次依然没有"I just can't. Sorry"之类的选项，你再次表达了"Just tell me!"的意愿，然后再一次由于™天杀的被续了的时间条，你必须再一次鸽掉已经很伤心的那个女孩子，让她就此"Whatever fk this"然后offline，之后几乎永远消失在你的聊天列表里。

想要做二选一的决定，有很多很多种方式，例如在某次聚会前让Emily和Evelyn同时向你提出邀请，而你不得不拒绝其中一个，在拒绝时可以选择是诚实坦白还是撒一个谎，前者导向GE而后者导向BE；又或者，第三章这种狗屎故事也还算能救，如果在一开始就能明确表达心意，拒绝其中一个女孩子就很简单明了。虽然被拒绝了的妹子还是会伤心，但是伤心也比[b]被信赖的人给予承诺然后发现自己被骗要好得多。[/b] 主角这种两面三刀的做法和Jeff或Steve有什么区别，甚至我觉得怎么看都要比他们俩还糟糕得多？

[h1]在一个女孩子遭遇了恋爱打击、心情非常低落的情况下，明明向她承诺了“I am always here”，之后却马上对她置之不理。满口说着"Sorry I have to do a thing"的敷衍托辞，可实际上不听她倾诉的真正理由，是因为你那时在安慰另一个失恋的女孩子。这样把伤心的女孩子当备胎的做法，真的非常、非常、非常恶心、卑劣和令人不适。[/h1]

可能是由于这是一款聊天软件而不是日式GAL，并且游戏中人物对话的风格非常接近现实日常[spoiler]Evelyn真的全程让我想到我的法国舍友........[/spoiler]我无法把这个故事当做“虚拟二次元笑笑就好”，而认为它应该是更真实一些的故事。[spoiler]如果真实世界里男性脚踏两条船也是正常操作的话，那我真是无话可说。[/spoiler] 再加上制作者设计了聊天窗不能全屏、profile资料互动以及Youtoob&Facenook等元素，进一步让我成功浸入到了这个小小的聊天游戏里，感觉我参与到的就是一段贴近现实的关系当中。

然而也很不幸的是，就是这种浸入感在第三章给我带来了猝不及防地一口喂屎，如果我对这个游戏没有那么共情，可能我的反应还不会如此激烈。

打完第三章之后进入第四章，看到Evelyn的头像就这么一直灰着，我的心情犹如是吃了一大口腹泻夹心费列罗。游戏是好游戏，制作组也确实用了心，在回收几个头像成就时，我也发现了一些很有意思的对话梗。我愿意上供我的玛尼，支持制作组继续做游戏，且如果续作不会有这种狗屎二选一，我肯定还是会购买。

但是对不起。对于Emily is Away Too，我实在是无法继续玩下去。

38225848.review:
The core of the game remains pretty much unchanged: You are a boy in your teens, you are messaging two girls now (instead of the one in the original) and you can choose diferent answers to stear the conversation.

The differences are little details -like the fact that each character has their favorite genre of music and recommends songs to each another (most of which I ended up really liking), downloading files to your actual desktop or that the developers have actually set up a fake internet which looks like it was from 2006 full of easter egg videos from that time- which actually go [b] a really long way [/b] to emerse you in the game!

The game also has some new mechanis like the fact that you can talk to two girls instead of one (and they do remember things you've said to them ;) ) and [b] SPOILER [/b] [spoiler] You get to choose which girl you like the most by deciding with which of them you want to speak more when they're both talking with you at the same time, which is a [b] much [/b] better way to do it than just asking you outright. Kudos to the devs for that. [/spoiler]

Also, the dialogue is [strike] really great [/strike] grand! It feels like a genuine conversation between two close friends and not a plotted conversation written by a man in his 50s.

Everything about this game draws you into the games world


[b] Now for the negatives: [/b]
The game is pretty short (my first playtrough took only 2.8h, and that is with exploring the fake internet quite extensibly, so I'd imagine my second one to be around maybe 2 hours...), but for those ~3 hours I've been really emersed in the game and didn't even realize how fast the time went by. And I can't say that about many games, especially at the 5$ mark.

Now you can obviously play the game multiple times and see all the options, which will bump up your playtime. I haven't played trough it again, but from what I saw other people say, [b] slight SPOILER [/b] [spoiler] the diferences between the two girls are minimal, but hey, if the dialogue is as good as with Emily, then I'll replay it at least once more [/spoiler]

Also other people have said that they got screwed over by some dialogues (especially with the inbetween-ey choices) where the main character said something diferent than what they thought he'd say. Hasn't been a problem in my playtrough, but I thought I'd mention it.

[b] HUGE SPOILER [/b] [spoiler] also, some of the reasons why you fight with Emily at the end make absolutley no sense; like in my playtrough I really connected with Emily (we liked the same music, I helped her with her "I'll kill myself if you leave me" boyfriend and what not) but in the end she dumped me becuse I told her I don't drink but told the other girl that I sometimes do... ARE YOU KIDDING ME?? Has she never heard of social drinking or what?

So how did she find this out? Oh, well she talked with this other girl and it turns out that "the version of me that she knew wasn't the same as the one the other girl knew", because as we all know, the most important thing about a man is wether he doesn't drink alcohol or [b] sometimes [/b] drinks alcohol. [/spoiler]


[b] So in conclusion [/b], this is just like the first game, just bigger and better. If you liked the first game, you should deffinetley pick this one up.
I can see why you might not want to buy it for just 3 hours of content, but those hours had an amazing atmosphere! (especially if you didn't play the first one!)

I 100% recomend this game, and it has made it up on my top 10 games list.

I really enjoyed watching Jack Septic Eye play the first game when I was 13 and I really enjoyed playing this one now.

38187540.review:
I played (and reviewed) a somewhat similar game in the past, Cibele. But where Cibele made me feel absolutely nothing about its characters and their online drama and shenanigans, Emily Is Away Too succeeded in making me care. Cibele's 74% on metacritic feels entirely and bafflingly undeserved by comparison.

Perhaps it's because EIAT resonates more with me as it speaks to some of my own experiences, not identical but not entirely different to the game's. Maybe it's because, unlike Cibele, you actually have choices to make in the duration of the game that affect where the story goes and how the two people you chat with view you or where the story ends. Maybe it's because the game captures the 2006~ era pretty well with its use of pseudo-ARG youtoob, facenook, profile icons and liberal use of lyrics and other pop culture references. Maybe it's because it's way better written. Without a single voice-acted line of dialogue, EIAT manages through its well-written dialogue complete with (on-purpose) spelling errors, facenook notes and statuses, different endings and creative uses of songs to paint its characters much better than the fully (and well) voice-acted Cibele ever did.

TL;DR: This game is a lot more fun and deep than you'd initially think it is. Especially for what amounts to an MSN Messenger simulator.

38101447.review:
Pra quem não jogou o primeiro (emily is away - é de graça!) sugiro jogar pra entrar no clima com esse game aqui.

Emily is away too é a simulação da sua vida na época de mIRC, msn e icq. Desde escolher as imagens de exibição da sua conta, músicas e até gírias usadas, todo esse conjunto trouxe uma nostalgia que nunca tinha experimentado na minha vida até então.

Duas coisas que achei demais:

1) As músicas que as gurias que você conversa te mandam via link do youtube. Você começa a escutar as músicas e elas te fazem entrar no clima mais ainda, lembrando justamente a época que aquele crush lhe mandava uma música e você escutava com atenção.

2) Recebimento de arquivos. Eu recebi um log de chat e um poema em formato txt, e o game salva na tua área de trabalho, bem legal. Inclusive quem te manda o arquivo comenta que está no teu desktop, haha.

O game vale totalmente o preço cheio, eu achei uma obra de arte. Jogos hoje em dia querem dar muita atenção em gráficos e monetização, mas às vezes esquecem o principal que é a diversão do usuário.

38090987.review:
As someone who started using the internet around 2003, I obviously used MSN a lot. That's how I met a lot of people who are still my best friends to this day. I think about those times a lot, and how real life was shitty because of depression, but my internet friends were always there for me.

This game looks simple on the surface, but it has a really deep emotional impact. You'll feel like these are people you really know, and get attached to them (well, not Emily.) Being friends with Evelyn made me feel so happy, like it was 2006 again. It reminded me of those memories that I cherished so much.

It helps to play the first game, only because it gives you a general idea of what this game is about (plus it's free.) EiAT has a lot more options though, as the first felt kind of limited.

If you grew up in a time where Numa Numa and LEAVE BRITNEY ALONE were the most popular videos on YouTube at the time, or you watched Metal Gear Awesome on Newgrounds, you will find a lot to relate to with this game. It will effect you a lot; kind of reminds me of Undertale in the sense that you feel a bond with these characters.

Do not lie to Emily. Do not lie to Evelyn. Trust me.

Never before have I felt guilty for not typing fast enough in a video game.

I spent the entire evening after finishing this game self-reflecting on people I've seen drift away over years, and the interactions of my early teens.

38009998.review:
[i]Emily étant un cas désespérant, je me suis tourné vers Evelyn. Sacrée Emily.[/i]

[i]Emily is Away Too[/i], sorti en 2017, est petit jeu indépendant où votre but est d'éviter à tout prix la mythique "FriendZone" dans laquelle vous tomberez à la moindre erreur ! [spoiler]Bon, j'ai quand même réussi mon coup avec Evelyn. J'ai laissé tombé avec Emily ^^[/spoiler]

[h1]Les plus :[/h1]

- L'histoire est plus intéressante que dans le premier opus. Là, on doit gérer deux dialogues (parfois en même temps, avec un temps pour répondre), et faire correspondre nos choix (ou pas ^^) pour ne rater la fin du jeu, et amadouer l'une des deux. Oui, ce jeu m'a transformé en une sorte de prédateur sexuel.
- Les Easter-Eggs sont plus complets que dans le premier. On a carrément des dialogues avec des personnages connus de la "pop-culture", avec un paquet de références à capter.
- Une meilleure durée de vie, environ 2h-2h30 pour finir le jeu, et on y rajoute 1h-1h30 pour les Easter-Eggs.
- Parfois, les dialogues nous amènent à cliquer sur des liens "Internet" (pas vraiment Internet, ce sont de fausses pages), et on y retrouve la vieille interface de Facebook, ou Youtube notamment (avec de vieilles vidéos cultes, et même notre joyeux Rick !)
- J'ai réussi à être Evelyn. [spoiler]DANS TA GUEULE EMILY ![/spoiler]

[h1]Les moins :[/h1]

- C'est toujours aussi chiant de taper sur le clavier comme un sourd pour écrire le texte. Perso, j'ai utilisé une manette pour bloquer les touches du clavier. Ingénieux n'est-ce pas ?

[h1]N.B. :[/h1]

- Evaluation de [i]Emily is Away[/i] --> [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198118392184/recommended/417860/]Voir ici[/url]

[h1]Conclusion :[/h1]

[i]Emily is Away Too[/i] est plus complet que son prédécesseur, avec plus de contenu, et enfin une fin heureuse ! :D

_ _ _ _

[h1]Si vous avez trouvé cette évaluation utile, venez rejoindre notre [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AlternaTyff#curation]page de curation et nos forums ![/url][/h1]

The first game isn't one I like to talk about since it saddens me to the point that I can't sleep.

This game is one I really want to talk about. It crafts a story where your choices really do matter and lying is something that makes you regret eventually down the line where It makes you feel like you caused it and just broke up with a girlfriend who-who had become really close to and had almost had the idea of falling in love with.

The appearance really sends you back to retro 2006 internet where the reference cause you to play around with real working weblinks and a retro-looking youtube page, internet references that bring back a lot of nostalgia, and just overall high school memories that it makes it all totally worth it enough that I was able to push the first game out of my head..........execpt for me going for emily because [u] I DESERVE MY EMILY [/u]

the characters (all two of them) are really interesting in their own right, both having their own personality and interests (and even a realistic story aspect where their personality and interestest can actually change depending on how close they get to you.). 

overall, this game is really entertaining even if it is short. You will have heartbreak, happyness, sadness, anger, etc (because there are multiple endings that happens depending on your choices.) and it keeps the whole game intresting from minute 1 to hour 7.1 in my case.

10/10 would travel back to 2006 and have fun on the internet while still getting to see Rick and morty in a kinda funny easter egg.

37763669.review:
Oh my god, the nostalgia....

Playing this game, I felt thrown back 10 years earlier, at the dawning of Instant Messenging (MSN how I miss you), when some of the greatest memes and websites of the internet were being born. 

I had played Emily is Away, the free prequel of this game and, for a symbolic couple of euros, I didn't even think a second about not buying this one. And I don't regret it even for a second. This game is just perfect in its simplicity.

The pitch : you are a highschool boy/girl (your gender is never assumed nor precised so you could play as either) and you are talking through an IM system to two girls, Emily and Evelyn, with their own character. Through a serie of discussions, you will shape the history of those two over the last year of highschool, and might even end up in a relationship with one of them. 

The first game (Emily is Away) was a lot about how IM-people were drama queens, and this one is a three-way interaction about how you can't solve everyone's problems at the same time through IM ; although if you don't play your cards right, there's quite some drama. Contrary to the first game, there are actually a couple of good endings, which is (IMO) quite an improvement from the first game. There are too a few immersion details : links you can click for good ol' 2006 music, "facenook" web profiles and files which download on your ACTUAL computer. So a working internet network is recommended to play this game. And dont miss the numerous memes/easter eggs !

So all in all, I would totally recommend this game. The nostalgia of this long gone time, especially if like me you have known it as a teenager, will leave you with quite a heavy heart when you will close the last window of the last discussion.

37720485.review:
first of all, I think you most definitely should buy it for all the effort that's been put in both Emily games by Kyle Seeley's team. They created a local time machine, no less, with all these references, sites, music and even your own desktop for **sake. Seriously, all these filled profiles with the content that changes from chapter to chapter have got me in the first place even in the previous game. And I adore these developers for that.
BUT. 
The first game was a whole product. It was basically a post factum told story on which you could barely have influence, and it was beautiful because of this fact: you could hate Emily, could despise the main character, but you'd still empathize the story, because it's recognizable, because it's to believe in. 
The second game gives you a lot more opportunities, it has more endings and feels quite bigger and more solid. But I believe that's a wrong impression, because in the end it gives you one week funservicing story. I'll explain myself: whatever your first ending will be, it will also show you others WORD BY WORD. (exept one, [spoiler] depending on weather you with whoever stayed together or not [/spoiler]). Having only one character, who you will never be able to get, is fine by me, but having two empty shells with different facades and WORD BY WORD same insides - not so much. Yes, they like different stuff, their boyfriends are shitty in diferent ways and..oh wait, that's all 'cause by the time you know it you'll have to choose one of them, and it will not matter any more, because they both are acting verbatim the same when it comes to your relationship. That makes the game not only unreplayble, but antireplayble, because any attempt to rewrite this story will show you how meaningless your previous experience was. 

that's it, folks. Give the creators money they well deserve, try to get from this game the most while completing it for the first time (and there's a lot to enjoy: go through the sites, your chat list profiles, unlock the icons and try appearing profiles too) and don't ever come back to it.
deuces

37225626.review:
[i]Emily, who is Emily? My mother would say she's everyone. Every [b]girl[/b], every [b]boy[/b], every [b]person[/b] that anyone has ever loved.[/i]

Con estas primeras palabras, casi a modo de estado de messenger, comienza Emily is Away Too. Después de un primer juego gratuito que me encantó e incluso me hizo rememorar viejos tiempos y me hizo sentirme muy identificado, llega una segunda parte, esta vez de pago pero a un precio ridículamente bajo, y con bastantes más opciones y profundidad que el primer juego. No es una continuación del primero, sino más bien una especie de reinicio donde volvemos a conocer a Emily, pero esta vez de forma distinta. Y quizá la novedad más destacable es que en esta ocasión hay una segunda chica: Evelyn.

Puede parecer una tontería, pero el hecho de que esta vez hablemos con dos personas diferentes hace que la historia adquiera nuevas capas de complejidad y ofrezca mucho más juego. Como es de esperar (el juego no engaña a nadie), se nos pondrá en la situación de elegir casi desde un primer momento: ¿Emily o Evelyn? Ambas amigas muy cercanas, y dos chicas que no podían ser más diferentes entre sí.

Primero está Emily, protagonista única del primer juego y que aquí conserva más o menos los mismos rasgos. La típica chica bien, educada, alegre, responsable, estudiosa y sana, al menos la mayor parte del tiempo. Y por el otro Evelyn, que prácticamente es su contraparte: la clásica chica rebelde, que fuma, bebe, se apunta a todas las fiestas y hasta es un poco malhablada, pero también muy simpática y popular, especialmente entre los chicos. Y puedo asegurar que es muy difícil decidir, y lo más probable es que tengas dudas hasta el último momento.

El juego usa el sistema de tres elecciones del primero, emulando la interfaz del viejo messenger, y esta vez sí, las decisiones importan y mucho, ya que hay una buena cantidad de finales, malos y buenos, y que involucran a una o a otra chica. Con esto, el principal punto negativo del primer juego está más que solucionado, ya que esta vez el juego es bastante más rejugable, y por si fuera poco dura algo más que el original.

En esta ocasión, además, todo es mucho más inmersivo. Las chicas nos pasarán enlaces a YouToob o Facenook, donde podremos escuchar la música que les gusta o echar un vistazo a su perfil y conocerlas un poco más, lo cual será útil más adelante si nos preguntan sobre el tema. Al final, si ya de por sí en el primero era fácil crear la ilusión de que por momentos estabas hablando con una persona real, aquí directamente te dejas llevar, y sorprende lo tremendamente humanas que resultan ambas chicas, fruto de lo bien escrita que está la historia.

Se podría decir que el primer juego funciona como una toma de contacto de cara a éste. Siendo gratis, recomiendo descargar el primero y probarlo. Si te gusta, esta segunda parte es más de lo mismo pero mucho mejor. Una historia que sin duda te dejará huella, y más aún si en su día conociste a tu propia (o propio) Emily.

[h1] This game exceeded all of my expectations. [/h1]
In the first game, you felt like you were the character, but sometimes you were forced to make decisions.

In this game I felt like I had total control, and I was responsible for my actions.

I love having consequences in this game, your actions can come back to haunt you, or to help you. You really do feel like you're affecting these girls and their lives. I felt guilt during a game, which is extremely rare. I felt like I was typing and really writing these heartfelt (or short and sarcastic) messages. You really do [b]feel[/b] like you're in the game. Seriously, for 5 dollars, there is not a better game you could buy. I would recommend playing the first one, because you can connect a lot better to the characters, but it's still a great standalone.

This game puts so much story and emotion into simple high-school drama. I felt sad. I was excited. I felt guilt. I felt anger. It was amazing, I wish there was so much more. I crave more of this game. Do yourself a favor and buy this game. You won't regret it.

36822710.review:
Got in a Humble Monthly bundle.

[h1]Pros:[/h1] Tiny bit of a nostalgia trip for people who were around the same age at around the same time as the characters.

[h1]Cons:[/h1] 
[b]Pointless story with no depth:[/b]
- Story is very short and extremely shallow. Could be summed up in two sentences or so:
- Two girls you apparently barely know exist and chat with you once a year. Through rather shallow discoveries in similar tastes, you can become friends, or possibly more. 
- Both girls are extremely whiny and annoying, constantly complaining about their terrible boyfriends, and you have to pretend to care deeply and think they're the best people ever, or they hate you, even though you barely know them or their terrible boyfriends.

[b]Annoying game mechanics:[/b]
- Either mash on the keyboard to type, or turn on type assist and wait for it to type painfully slowly for you
- Forced "argument" in Chapter 3 where no matter what you do, you can't respond quickly enough and both girls are mad at you over not responding quicker than they even do sometimes.
- To get the best endings, forced to open weird external websites (in your own web browser) that are copies of well-known websites and process what's happening on them. For example, one song page is broken, if you say you liked the song, the girl knows you didn't listen to it. It's an interesting concept, but if you want the game to be immersive, why not just put these things in-game, rather than using my browser?
- Another interesting concept that could have been done in-game - it has you download a desktop background to put as your desktop on your real computer. Why not full-screen the game and really set up the immersion, a la Orwell? Instead of having me download desktops and set the game's immersion up for you...

[h1]tl;dr - [/h1]
Concept is interesting. Game is extremely annoying unless you like whiny shallow chats. Can't recommend to friends. As an achievement addict I'm actually dreading going back in and trying to get the rest of the achievements.

36822226.review:
Got this in a bundle and did a quick playthrough of the first game before I started this. They captured the vibe and feel of the era, the fake youtube playlists, the alert sounds, the references. User profiles! Nostalgia overload.

I'll preface this by saying I'm a gay dude, so I wasn't sure how much I could connect with a young hetero guy, but some things are the same for everyone I guess. The awkwardness and wanting to please even if it means lying a bit, the confusion, being forced to choose between two people you care about and dealing with their reactions, the drifting apart. So much of it hit home. My teenage angst will be with me well into my thirties.

For those in the right age group consider this a nostalgia simulator. For anyone else this prolly won't appeal to you much but it certainly has its merits. I wouldn't label this a game so much, there are some choices to be made in the sequel but you're basically just there for the ups and downs of the ride.

Emily is Away Too: A game with a unique concept and great atmosphere that leaves you disappointed with pisspoor writing that railroads you into emotional conflict without creating a valid or interesting pretense. 

Literally every single conflict in this game is enforced through mechanics. After trying about 9 times, chapter 3 seems impossible to complete without disappointing anyone thanks to the limits on typing speeds & the countdown timer. The final chapter forces you to fight with whichever friend you sided with, through an instance where they take away your agency. Even if you seemingly help your friend calm down, out of nowhere they will suddenly be angru again just so you can feel bad. If the point of the narrative is the volatile and brittle relationships in highschool, they enforced it poorly by introducing frustrating & unfun mechanics. If that isn't the point of the narrative, then this was a guilt trip of solely contrivance and I don't recommmend it at all.


I thought they learned something from the first game, but no. They both suffer from awful, awfui writing problems. Will not be checking out future content from these developers.

36641786.review:
I received this game from a Humble Monthly bundle, and am really glad I did so instead of paying directly for it. The TLDR of this game is that it trades the genuine dialogue and emotional writing of the first game for some immersive elements (Facebook + Youtube recreations) and ability to talk to [b]two[/b] girls. It's very disappointing.

So much of the conversation in this game feels contrived to incorporate gameplay elements, eg they will ask "btw, do you remember what my favorite movie genre is???" like this is a flash dating simulator. They'll become outraged and bring up a line of dialogue you said in the first chapter and use that to make judgements about your character in the last chapter, a full year later. There's a point where you have to respond within a certain time frame (3-4 seconds) or they'll become irate and end their conversation with you. Nobody talks or acts like this in real life. The artificiality and obvious gameplay mechanics really hurt the writing quality and ability to connect with the characters.

This game is still great as a charming nostalgia trip for those who used AIM in the 2000s - they'll mention films, songs, bands from then, and when you select your AIM buddy icon at the beginning of the chapter you'll see many images of albums, memes, and other pop phenomenon that you probably haven't seen since 2006. But the first game did that just fine, and that game is free.

I wouldn't pay more than $2 for this game and only if you thoroughly enjoyed the first, because this game is inferior to that. $5 is way steep considering there's no replay value to this and the paths are near identical until they divulge near the end.

36640183.review:
It's a retro pixel desktop emulator.  You can't make this stuff up, that's how low the indy movement has sunk. 

Of course there's more to it than really low quality desktop emulation.   You are some high school kid trying to date some high school girls.  So it's a retro pixel text based dating sim presented through desktop emulation.   I don't know how drunk I would have to be before that seemed like a good premise for a "game". 

I get the developer is trying to do "art", but "art" for the most part doesn't belong on Steam, and retro pixel graphics are the art equivalent of elephants flinging paintbrushes in the general direction of a canvas.   Only not as good.

There's a lot of complaints about the quality of the story, too, but the interface was so painful I thankfully couldn't get that far. 

Can't recommend this, it's not really a game, and the production quality is terrible.

36629863.review:
Alright.

So I played through this game last night, not knowing really what to expect. I just wanted a game where choices had some sway on how the story played out, and for 4.99 USD, Emily Is Away Too seemed like a great option.

I really liked the game. It was a nice way to kill some some time. The characters, Emily and Evelyn, are pretty generic, I guess, but in a way that really works for the game. The music was pretty awesome, and it really took me back and made me feel old (especially since the game takes place about 11 years, from the current date, ago). Gameplay consists of pressing tab, 1, 2 ,3, and pretending you're a world class typist typing at a bajillion GWAM. You *can* use the mouse to click on options as well, but I haven't found it necessary.

The one thing I wasn't really a fan of was that the concept of nuance seems to be lost on Emily and Evelyn, and certain choices you make with nuance in mind can negatively affect your relationships with either character. There are multiple endings that depend on how honest you are with the characters, so keep that in mind when you're selecting the options.

It starts off really fun, but it can get real at times.

I absolutely loved the first 4 chapters of the game, emily and evelyn are amazing well made characters that feel real and that they had real emotions. This is glaringly seen when Evelyn asks you about your plans after college, and the more passive option of "I guess maybe" turns straight into "I definitely want kids 100% in the future" (I can't find the exact text of that part of the game within a decent time, around chapter 2 I think) Then finally,
 during chapter 5, this comes back and you're accused of lying and manipulating both of them. I understand what they were going for, but for me and what seems to be quite a few others in similar senarios too, nothing more than a "GOTCHA" mechanic to ruin chapter 5 [/spoiler]

Overall, the game isn't BAD, it's just disappointing from these dev because I feel like they put so much work in, then just got tired after a point.

I'm sorry, but just go buy VA-11 HALL-A, in my opinion is better written and although it can be a little "gotcha" at a point, it's not nearly as harsh
