36544712.review:
In this game, there are two main characters: Emily and Evelyn. Emily likes alternative music, does not like to drink, doesn't want kids, and hasn't had sex. Evelyn likes punk music, enjoys drinking, wants to have a family, and has had sex. Emily has a scumbag boyfriend named Jeff; Evelyn has a scumbag boyfriend named Steve.

Got it? Good, because those are the only differences between the two characters. They'll make sure you know it, too, constantly giving you quizzes on things they've said before and sometimes directly rating how close you've said your interests are to theirs.

The climax of the game comes when both of them start messaging you at the same time, both having almost the exact same boyfriend troubles, and the game transforms into a competition of jumping back and forth between the two to hammer out a response as fast as possible, because if you don't reply in five seconds they assume you're not paying attention even though the UI makes it clear that both people are supposed to be able to see when the other is typing. This turns what should be a serious set of conversations into a juggling competition of mashing your keyboard and making sure you don't get the girls' boyfriends' names mixed up since their circumstances are the exact same. 

Occasionally, the game does a gimmick where you choose a response and your actual character isn't brave enough to type it, so they say something else. This is almost neat -- except that at least  one of these changed responses leads directly to a "bad" ending where Emily accuses you of lying and breaks off the relationship. There is no way whatsoever to know that this is coming, and it comes at the end of the game based off something that the game did without your input an hour ago. The response is also an absurd overreaction to the point that it completely obliterates the idea that this character could ever be a real person. 

Overall, the concept was nifty as a free half-hour-long game,  but the addition of another character with only tiny variations is not enough to warrant even five bucks of your time.

Emily is back in black (Well Evelyn is anyway)!

For the most part this game takes the concepts and ideas of the first one and turns them up to 10 which is great if you found yourself falling in love with eol instant messanger in the first one. The new link features develop a living and pixelating world that really brings you back to a simpler time.

Getting lost in the nostalgia bomb doesn't just stop there because you're back in highschool and all of the petty drama associated with it one again. Kyle Seeley does a great job of setting you in that environment with text and music alone. With the main focus being your interactions with these 2 new girls you have to get attached to them and their problems which should come easily to most due to Seeley's good writing.

At points however, the text does feel a bit formulaic and robotic and it's a little odd that your character only speaks in absolutes but if you can find yourself getting over that then this is a altogether nice and emotional story of words and actions.

36406579.review:
It's scary to think that the sequel to a popular visual novel, which cost me £4, is my second choice for Game of The Year, along with Cuphead. But it's true. This game improves on the first in nearly every way, which is something many games fail to do nowadays. The two characters are more fleshed out and interesting, there's plenty of avatar icons that add new chat sequences, choices that actually affect your outcome at the end, and a solid pixel art style. The fact that these characters that are essentially faceless have more personality than most characters in AAA games is mind-blowing. And it's all by ONE guy. I understand that this game isn't for everyone, but for me, it's a solid entry to an already excellent game, and it has a decent amount of replay value, with the choices and all the chat sequences.

Here's hoping for Emily is Away Three sometime in the near future. Okay, maybe not.

36373658.review:
Vale, si os había gustado el Emily is Away, y odiasteis el final, TENEIS QUE JUGAR ESTE. 

Una vez hecha la recomendación, no os aconsejo seguir leyendo para poder ir FULL SURPRISE si os fiais de mí. Sino, allé voy:

El juego mejora por muchos motivos. Es mucho más largo, hay más opciones, más formas de resolverlo, y sin duda más finales. Aunque depende de lo que consideres un final distinto, claro. Pero me creo que hay 3 diferenciados y variaciones. 

Lo que más llama la atención es como el juego te hace creer que realmente estás escribiendo con alguien. Te pone los chats, la gente conectándose y desconectándose, la gente te habla o tú le hablas, tienes perfiles (tanto tuyo modificable como de otros)... Y lo mejor: utiliza links para páginas sociales, vídeos o incluso te descarga archivos. Queda muy realista, y eso le da mucho a favor. Se hace bastante original. 

Los personajes (ya que por fin no es solo uno, aunque tampoco es que aumente mucho...) son bastante carismáticos. Te cuentan su vida, y en seguida sabes de que rollo van. En tu mano está mentirles, decirles la verdad aunque pueda doler, mostrarte simpático, o demasiado incluso... 

Lo mejor de todo es que, para acabar en un final, no hace falta ir al 100% en algo. Por poner un ejemplo: aunque tú sepas que la otra persona ha dicho que le gusta la comedia, no hace falta que digas que a ti también para caerle mejor. Puedes ser tú mismo, decirle que te gusta el horror, o cualquier cosa. Te recordará que no os gusta lo mismo, pero al final eso no importará. 


Y finalmente, aunque ya he dicho "lo mejor de todo", esto me ha encantado: NO TODOS LOS FINALES TE LLEVAN A SENTIRTE COMO LA MIERDA Y A ODIAR UN PERSONAJE. Pueden acabar bien, MUY bien :) Por fin... 

PD: EVE IS BAE.

36372100.review:
This isn't anything revolutionary, but does have an undeniable charm and sense of nostalgia. 

The mechancis are simple. An AOL type chat is simulated, and you have a few choices when responding. The dialogue takes place between yourself and two girls, and you are given ample wiggle room to either try to appease both, ignore one completely, or let one down in a gentle manner. The concept is simple, but the atmosphere around it as well as some sequences which are timed add a slight sense of urgency and stress. There are moments where both characters are simultaneously attempting to vent to you in a very realistic and emotional manner, and failure to reply will leave them lost and angry, degrading your relationship with them. In this way, you must pick and choose your words as to keep friends close yet also give a clear message as to your own feelings towards the characters as to not lead them on in a way. After completing a few chapters, the characters attitude towards you, and in turn your options for how to handle situations, are more clearly defined as they had been shaped by your previous interactions. Overall, this game brings a compelling and engaging visual novel type experience to a unique aesthetic veiled in nostalgia that makes the dialogue all the more believable.

This experience isn't without its flaws though. Some of the dialogue includes phrases and references to your own previously stated interests that seem somewhat robotic and unnatural, and can lead to some weird breaks in an otherwise believable conversation. While these spots are usually overshadowed by the story that unfolds immediately after, they do stain the experience in a way. 

The moments of stress, balancing two conversations, force you to become more involved and ask yourself which characters have given you reason to care for them over the other. You aren't forced to pursue either character in a romantic way, but leaning too far either way will cause the other to question your motives. While this mechanic mostly adds to the experience in terms of creating an anchor for emotion investment by allowing you to dynamically interact with two character archetypes, the timed sequences can sometimes lead to a rushed feel leaving the player without an option to recover. Immediately after these strange moments of disconnect, though, the story picks up again. However, choices made early in the game might end up stinging later on. Without spoiling why that is, I recommend consistency with however you choose to build your character. You can build them purposely to be unlikeable and pretentious, but can also do so indirectly which may affect the outcome later down the line. After completing a playthrough, I came to really appreciate how impactful some early-game decisions are, though there is a frustration in those decisions destroying your chances and interactions with whichever character you had taken to if you indirectly set yourself up for failure. In a way, though, this creates some replayability, and I'm personally starting over taking the ending I got into account and trying to follow a similar, but better path. The continuous stream of chat messages and various options can at least keep you engaged with the one character you manage to stick with the most, though, even if you completely ruin your chances with the other.

In terms of replayability, there are also secret profile icons that are unlocked via certain actions or getting a certain ending. After completing my second playthrough I can foresee myself coming back to this game later on to mess around with the extra stuff unloacked via these secret icons. This includes allowing you to chat with some interesting characters and mess around in a separate storyline from the get-go, completely ignoring the main game. This ranges from comical to in-depth and gives you something to come back to in order to experience the atmosphere of this game with a new, more lighthearted chat to play through. The first secret icon I got has allowed me to equip it and chat with a bot who initiates the player into some space force thing. It seems charming and entertaining enough, so I'll be checking it out after my current playthrough. The fact that there are extra fully scripted chat experiences that stray from the serious-toned drama of the main game is appreciable and adds to this product's value as well as displays the devs care for this game as the extra unlockable content is built into the main game and not shoved behind a microtransaction paywall. 

The real star of the show here, obviously, is the aesthetic. While the heavy reliance on low-pixel iconography does seem out of place in certain areas (even in 2007, apps weren't this low-res), the ambient audio as well as audio triggered through mouse clicks and keystrokes serve to immerse you in the atmosphere this game is trying to create. 

However, the aspect of this game I have to truly commend the dev on is the various links and images presented throughout. When first launching the game you are asked in-game what you want your wallpaper to be as well as a few other things. The extra care taken by the developer is apparent once you click the set wallpaper button and realize that the in-game "picture saved to your desktop" prompt also refers to the wallpaper file being sent to your actual desktop giving you the option to set your actual computer's wallpaper to that of the game. While this is sort of a gimmicky immersion, it does add to the feeling that there was genuine care and passion put into this game. 

The links that characters send you via chat are clickable as well, and lead to various webpages that parody YouTube, Facebook, and other nostalgic web entertainment of the time such as the blue ball machine. Not only are these web pages stylized to match the game, when characters send you a link to hear a song they've been listening to, the actual YouTube video is embedded amongst the stylized parody comment threads and interface. The stylized related videos tab also leads you down a rabbithole of nostalgia as you are able to watch many classic videos of the time without leaving the stylized parody site. While this isn't any prodigious web design by any means, the fact that there are multiple versions of these parody sites accessible through the game shows the amount of effort that has gone into creating an immersive atmosphere and triggering that sense of nostalgia. 

In conclusion, this game isn't for everyone. Being in a similar format to a visual novel, it isn't super interactive, but this game does offer more in the way of impactful decision making than most and has an atmosphere and aesthetic created out of passion that also bleeds into your actual computer which creates a unique charm unmatched by any game in this genre. It is a short experience, completed in a few hours, but if you allow yourself to be swept away into a classic he-said-she-said, cringey, emotional, drama-infused 2000's chat experience you won't regret the time spent. I'd say its worth the $5.00 price tag simply to support the work the dev has put into creating the atmosphere and story of this game, as it does improve most of what was great about the original. 

This isn't anything groundbreaking, but if you have a soft spot for mid 2000's internet activity, this is an experience you will definitely want to enjoy. 

--- review marked as "recieved for free" since I got this through November's Humble Monthly ---

36334435.review:
Mais uma vez, Kyle Seeley criou uma experiência em que a nostalgia é a principal mecânica. Mais do que as escolhas de diálogo, são os momentos em que o jogo nos transporta para o nosso próprio passado que fazem dele algo diferente e especial de tudo o resto no mercado. O título sabe como recriar as diferentes experiências de diferentes jogadores e enquadrá-las numa única história, numa única aventura que consiste apenas em conversas online com amigos e interesses amorosos, algo que todos nós fizemos a dada altura da vida, mesmo que com interfaces distintos.

Um dos principais méritos de Emily is Away Too é a forma como utiliza essas mecânicas para nos manter ligados a uma experiência que, no final de contas, é extremamente simples. Os efeitos sonoros clássicos do Windows, o processo de instalação falsa que marca o seu início, a possibilidade de definir nome, alcunha, ícone de chat - Nickelback, The Fray, Juno, That 70’s Show, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion, Sims 2, Scrubs, The Wire e Taking Back Sunday são algumas das opções -, mudar a cor de fundo e a cor da letra, bem como definir através de diferentes escolhas o vosso texto de perfil, são elementos que pouco ou nada influenciam a narrativa, mas que são absolutamente indispensáveis para capitalizar na nostalgia de quem o joga.
Dividido em diferentes capítulos que retratam vários momentos da vida de um estudante do último ano do secundário e que tem lugar entre 2006 e 2007, Emily is Away Too diferencia-se do seu irmão mais velho ao introduzir duas personagens com as quais podem conversar, muitas vezes em simultâneo. Emily e Evelyn, duas amigas do protagonista com gostos e personalidades distintos, assim como os seus próprios problemas relativamente a temas do coração, o futuro, os estudos, amizades, etc. Será uma narrativa algo familiar para aqueles que jogaram o título original, mas a verdade é que volta a ser executada com mestria através de diálogos e interações credíveis entre as personagens.

As conversas sobre absolutamente nada, o drama juvenil tradicional, o sarcasmo e a ironia sempre indispensáveis, está tudo aqui e resulta de forma notável, elevando a experiência a um patamar superior de qualidade. Entre as novidades está também a introdução de hiperligações para o YouToob e Facenook - versões fictícias de YouTube e Facebook com estética inspirada na sua aparência original - com o jogo a fazer uso de muita música licenciada através deste método e a revelar mais informações sobre as duas garotas através das suas páginas na rede social. São mais pormenores a adensar a nostalgia, mas podiam ter sido utilizadas de forma mais frequente e diversificada.

Falemos então agora do que não resulta. Os finais alternativos oferecem mais possibilidades e personalizam um pouco a experiência, mas são algo abruptos e, mais desapontante do que isso, estão muito longe de ter o impacto conseguido pelo primeiro título. Também não ajuda que os diferentes percursos sejam demasiado semelhantes e quebrem um pouco a magia da vossa primeira aventura pela obra. Querem um conselho? Não o joguem mais que uma vez, não vale a pena e isso apenas servirá para deixar um sabor amargo na vossa boca.

No terceiro capítulo existe um segmento que envolve duas conversas em simultâneo com limites de tempo que tem como objetivo forçar-vos a optar pela conversa que mais vos interessa, uma vez que é praticamente impossível manter as duas em movimento sem negligenciar uma delas ou até mesmo ambas. Percebe-se o porquê de existir, isto é, existe para vos forçar a decidir e a seguir um rumo em direção aos diferentes finais, mas o que é certo é que acaba por estragar momentaneamente o melhor que o título tem para oferecer, transformando demasiado a experiência num jogo propriamente dito.

Emily is Away Too é uma sequela que expande o conceito do seu antecessor e que volta a entregar uma experiência rica em valor nostálgico que nos faz regressar a um outro período da nossa vida com sucesso. A magia que tornou Emily is Away tão especial continua bem presente, mesmo que por vezes demasiado familiar, mas é inegável que as conclusões estão longe de ter o mesmo impacto que os últimos minutos do título original. Ainda assim, Emily is Away Too é uma obra de recomendação fácil a um preço acessível que pode ser concluída numa única sessão de jogo.

36319634.review:
Emily is Away Too é um jogo de aventura que seu personagem é levado à uma era pré-histórica e aí você... Ok, não é necessariamente isso.

Tudo se passa muitos anos atrás, bem no início da popularização da internet (época conhecida pela internet discada), e em Emily is Away Too você é apenas mais um estudante com suas preocupações de adolescente, no jogo usando um programa de mensagens instantâneas antigo, bem similar ao famoso MSN.

Esse jogo é a versão completa de [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/417860/Emily_is_Away/]Emily is Away[/url], que é gratuita.

[h1]Jogabilidade[/h1]

Não existe muito segredo, no jogo você conversa com duas pessoas: Emily e Evelyn, duas amigas importantes suas. Usando o chat você interage e faz escolhas para as respostas que vai dar para as garotas, tendo até três opções por mensagem delas. A história toda se desenvolve a partir das suas decisões no que responder para elas, onde cada capítulo é um ano da vida dos personagens, as escolhas impactam no que acontecem após a conversa terminar.

O jogo possui várias rotas além de sistemas interessantes que usam o próprio navegador do seu computador para maior imersão, como sites que são linkados para você durante a conversa. Todo o visual dele é semelhante ao do jogo, sendo bem gostoso de experimentar.

[h1]História e Enredo[/h1]

Como muitos desses jogos 'casuais' de escolhas, não há muito a ser apresentado anterior do jogo começar, tudo que lhe é dito é que você é só mais um adolescente usando o serviço de mensagens para falar com seus amigos.

O destaque mesmo é como já dito, tudo se desenvolver a partir de suas escolhas, dando possibilidades de várias rotas e finais diferentes. A ideia é boa e muito bem apresentada, sendo o principal [i]feature[/i] do jogo.

[h1]Trilha Sonora[/h1]

Inexistente. Tudo que é oferecido são links do velho youtube tocando músicas que as personagens gostam. No fim, acaba sendo a trilha sonora do jogo, afinal é muito fácil clicar e voltar ao que estava fazendo, deixando a música rolar no fundo. É interessante, representa bem essa época onde adolescentes ficavam horas conversando e ouvindo músicas.

[h1]Visuais[/h1]

Um charme a parte. Tudo é em pixelart, mas não tão detalhado, dando uma sensação de baixa qualidade em tudo, embora dê pra entender claramente o que o jogo mostra, seja covers de banda ou até mesmo personagens fictícios. 

É muito interessante também como eles fizeram os sites customizados no mesmo estilo, sendo extremamente divertido observar os detalhes de aparências antigas de sites como Youtube, Facebook ou até o próprio Steam.

[h1]Conclusão[/h1]

Jogo barato, divertido e simples, onde você faz escolhas e ferra sua vida igual todo adolescente. Mentira, não é pra tanto. É possível, apesar de tudo.
Recomendado principalmente se gostou da versão gratuita, afinal é quase como uma versão "Demo" só que mais linear.

36298775.review:
Emily is Away wasn’t the first visual novel I had ever played, but one of the few to transport me into a period of my life I thought I left behind. Maybe that was due more to the accurate recreation of Windows XP and AOL Instant Messenger from 2002 (even if it was in pixel art), but I had experienced many of the same scenarios the game covered.

It was heartbreaking to see my own mistakes and know what I could have done to prevent them. By that same measure, it made me realize that I’m not the only person to have felt the same way in such a situation, even if I beat myself up over my choices every day.

It wasn’t perfect (the characters were basically one-dimensional), but Emily is Away was effective in at least capturing a time period that seemed to disappear overnight. So what could a sequel possibly add to that? How about two potential love interests and multiple endings!The biggest change to the narrative design in Emily is Away Too is that you have more direct control over the branching paths. Choices you make in conversations with Emily and Evelyn, the two ladies of interest, will see you either ending up with one of them or ending up alone. While it’s easy to replay a chapter and get the exact outcome you want, robbing the game of any dramatic effect, at least you can be an active part of the plotline and avoid some of the negative aspects that plagued the first game (specifically, the scene where you may have unintentionally raped Emily).

The other big change comes in the form of an interactive recreation of 2006 Internet with Emilyisaway.com. The game now acts more like how AOL Instant Messenger was; what I mean is, everything you do in the game is through the guise of an instant messenger window instead of a recreation of a desktop with the application.

There are parts throughout the story where Emily or Evelyn will send you links to their "Facenook" pages or "YouToob" videos and those work through your own browser (which I suppose means the game requires an internet connection). They also send chat logs and homework to you that will dump to your actual desktop for you to look at. If you want, you can even browse through YMTND and find hilariously stupid videos from 2006. It definitely creates a much more authentic experience of the time period, though I’m not entirely sure why this couldn’t be contained within the application.

36288875.review:
I'm going to give this a thumbs up but it's a difficult decision. The Youtoob and Facenook stuff is just wonderful. The dialogue is quite limited, however, and subsequent playthroughs it becomes painfully obvious how so. There's no option to, say, NOT accept someone's apology after they curse at you. There's no option to defend your choices with "I changed my mind, as humans are known to do." And the game does suffer from what I want to call Bioware text, or maybe Bethesda text.. you can never be 100% sure that you're reading the tone of your chosen response correctly, and once you choose an option, the text comes out and there's no way to go back. It doesn't hurt the story much, but it is a little unrealistic.

There's also a huge amount of passive aggression in the cast, with some potential emotional abuse that borders on gaslighting. If you realize that you're playing a teen talking to teens, it's easier to understand that these people don't know how healthy relationships work and are still trying to figure it out. But at the same time, it can sometimes feel really gross to be stuck in these situations - and I fear that for too many people, these sorts of interactions are just what they accept as being normal in a relationship.

If you enjoyed the first, even with its limitations, I think you'll find this worth playing.

36266750.review:
Emily is Away Too is a sequel to the surprising popular free game "Emily is Away".
If you haven't played it, I highly recommend it. 

The second game's very similar to the first one in concept, but it adds a lot of depth. 
Manipulating your desktop, adding multiple conversations to go at the same time and the biggest thing of all... it makes its own Internet environment. Fake Facebook, fake Youtube, fake troll pages, fake remixes. 
It was a blast discovering everything the game had hidden away and given to you.

The game has a cool story, though it's a bit shallow. I think the format and everything they've done just carries it enough to keep the game engaging. 
Now, the game "officially" doesn't have a soundtrack, but that doesn't stop them from having their fake Youtube play period-appropriate popular music. It adds a lot to the atmosphere and is a very clever way of getting around copyright laws. 

I got this from a Humble Monthly (which I forgot I had) and I'm happy to say, that deal was worth it for me. 
Would I buy it for the full price? No, but I don't buy anything at full price. 
Is it worth it during almost any sale? I'd say so. 
It's not an amazing narrative or the most interactive game ever, but it's definitely a cool enough experience to pay the price of a McDonald's meal for.

36266116.review:
Not recommended due to its 'play it the way I designed it or suffer in hell' design. You either play it exactly the way the designer wanted you to play it (aka with no inconsistencies in your choices, even the choices are asked at different points of time in the game). The first four of five chapters are excellent renditions of the early 00s chat culture, but dear god that mess that is Chapter 5. 

You'll be asked a few questions during chapter 1 and 2, which you're expected to give the exact same answers to, which is absurd. One example, in Chapter One you're asked whether you drink, and you can choose to say no. In Chapter 2, a few months later in game time, another character asks you the same question and you're given the choice to say 'just a bit.' In real high school life, people experiment, and so that answer can be entirely truthful, but the damnation of seven hells on you if you choose that, because the game then screams INCONSISTENCY, BLASPHEMY, BURN HIM, HE LIED THE FIRST TIME, except, of course, you're never told that till the final act (and to get the 'good ending you'll have to replay chapters 2-5). You're punished for growing as a character, oh joy. =_=

Any one 'discrepancy' instantly throws you off into the very bad end. I'm not kidding. And there are atleast three other similar questions that cause the same result. It just feels terrible, it undermines the spirit of freedom the game seems to have in the first four chapters.

 6/10, nice if you like a fake Choose Your Own Adventure which is really just choose one specific path, otherwise I'd recommend 'quitting' the game after Chapter 4. If you're willing to play by the dev's rules, go ahead and play Chapter 5 (I'd say take a look at the recommended answers, but that'd kill the fun of experimentation, which is why this design stinks). If it's your first run, and you don't get the doghouse ending, you'll probably enjoy this game more than I did.

If you were a teenager in the 00's, this is the game for you.

This game captures, quite amazingly, a perfect snapshot of teenage life on the internet in the mid-2000's. The chat messenger, the video pages, Google... It's identical to the way they looked back in the day, and it was a fun little trip that really gives you a deep immersion. Even though the story wasn't my own, I definately felt like a teen again, and all the emotions from those days came bubbling up as I played.

Truly, this sweet little game is a gem, and was worth every minute, for both nostalgia and for a neat little story.

I miss you, Milly. I know I never really did all I could for you but I tried to be there for you. I hope you are still well and that you got what you wanted. As for me and Evelyn, we still keep in touch but it never was the same as with you. You were always the one for me.

And thus my time with these characters ended with a lot of confusing feelings. It almost felt like it all actually had taken place. Yeah, the dialogue is "cringey", as some adults would call it, but teenagers do speak like this. At least we did when I was in high school. The websites feel authentic, the music is spot-on and all other nuances make it a fantastic game.

I would recommend this to anyone who likes realistic simulators, drama and just immersing themselves in a setting. Believe me, it is worth it. Especially if you manage to get feelings for Emily or Evelyn. I did and it breaks my heart that I couldn't have it as I wanted to, but at the same time, not every mistake is a regret.

My first and only girlfriend #feelsbadman. Anyway, this game was great, and it had multiple endings unlike the first one which all ended in pretty much the same scenarios. But the game doesn't have the same ending impact as the first one did, which pretty much almost made me cry and brought me a huge depression for about 10 minutes. The most intense moment was chapter 3, but I won't spoil it. It pretty much decides the ending. Anyway, the first is a great free game and this one is pretty work the asking price even though it's not that long. 9/10

36110319.review:
От первой части меня крыло. Меня так многое раздражало в первой части. Как так? Почему в этой истории нету выбора? Почему ничего не зависит от игрока? Почему история каждый раз идёт по одному и тому же сценарию, какие бы верные/неверные варианты я не выбирал. Но было в этом своё очарование. Создатели игры рассказали историю. И игровой процесс был лишь просто выбранным вариантом повествования. И эта история понравилась мне. Есть человек, который когда-то был важен и близок, но жизнь развела вас, вы постепенно стали чужими друг другу. И это никак не поменять. Это надо постараться принять. Принять и жить дальше. Игровой процесс помог лучше прочувствовать историю, ощутить её, наполнил эмоциями. Как игрок, я был разочарован, мне казалось это не правильным. Но как созерцатель, я оценил. Как созерцатель, я, чем больше проходит времени, тем больше наполняюсь восхищением от этой игры.
Во второй части этого нету. Во второй части есть выбор, большее количество концовок. Теоретически всё зависит от игрока. И как игрок я это оценил, я ждал именно этого. Но сама история, сам проект из-за этого проигрывает первой части.
При этом игра погружает в себя больше, сильнее, нежели первая часть. Всё же тут чат не с одной девушкой, а с двумя. И иногда надо стараться писать им побыстрее. Кроме того, игра постоянно присылает ссылки на музыкальные видео, девушки предлагают переписываться и слушать вместе один альбом. Это потрясающе, мне так кажется.
Словом, большую часть игры, мне очень нравилось. Меня захватывало, мне нравилась атмосфера и история. Мне нравилось то, какие эти девушки разные. Мне нравились выборы, перед которыми меня ставили.
А потом была концовка игры. И это было бредово. То есть, вот я нахожусь в отношениях с девушкой. Мы знакомы года два. Мы дружим. Нам всегда было весело друг с другом. У нас разные музыкальные вкусы, разный образ жизни, но нам всё равно хорошо вместе. Я приходил ей на помощь в сложной ситуации. У нас всё гармонично. И когда-то давно, когда мы только сближались, я сказал ей, что хочу в будущем крепкие отношения и семью. И в то же время, когда-то давно, год назад, я сказал другой девушке, что прямо сейчас не хочу остепеняться, что я не готов ещё к серьёзным отношениям, что прямо сейчас я не готов к семье. В моей голове это не противоречащие друг другу тезисы. И вот теперь моя девушка узнала об этом. И решила расстаться со мною. Потому что: я не тот человек, которого она знала. Потому что выходит, что я пытался манипулировать кем-то из них. Потому что эта ситуация, по ей мнению очень весомая. Я дескать, хитрый манипулятор, она больше никогда не сможет мне верить. И она не готова видеться со мною, не готова говорить. Что это за бред?
А ничего, что мы лучшие друзья? А ничего, что мы общаемся два года? И если я за эти два года не вызывал у тебя никаких вопросов, может ты выслушаешь меня? Серьёзно, из-за того, что год назад я другой девушке сказал, что пока не готов к семье, а тебе в это же самое время сказал, что мысль о семье меня не отторгает? Гениальный повод для прекращение всякого общения!
Игра, ты чего? Главное, я даже не понял, что сказал им разные вещи. Игра полностью на английском, может быть, я чего-то не догнал. Но я старался быть искренним с ними, говорить им одно и то же. Там просто ситуации были разные, поэтому и реакция от меня была разная.
И мне бы хотелось перепройти игру. Открыть другие концовки. Потому что я отказываюсь принимать эту. Я не верю этой концовке. Евелин не стала бы вести себя так. Потому что это бред. Это полный бред. Мне бы хотелось перепройти игру, но она проходится довольно долго. У меня, вот прохождение заняло четыре с половиной часа. И она довольно однообразная. Я не ожидаю, что она принесёт мне какие-то новые эмоции вплоть до самой концовки. А это отторгает всякое желание играть в неё.
Очень странное у меня осталось послевкусие. То есть, был момент в игре, в котором я счастливо улыбался, как дебил. Мне очень понравилось, как у меня менялось отношение к этим девушкам, когда я узнавал о них побольше. Мне очень зашла атмосфера. Всё было круто. Но концовка. Почему? Как? Это было абсолютно нелогично.

36076108.review:
This game is excellent! Sure, the plots are incredibly linear and Emily and Evelyn are maybe a little too similar. But the game still manages to feel real. It still feels like I'm not playing a game, but rather actually talking to people. The Facenook and Youtoob links, choice of pixelated XP backgrounds, and file transfers do make for a more immersive experience. I'm too young to have first-hand experience with the atmosphere of the early days of social media, but I do have many memories of XP and that is captured really well.

I think it's a shame that the dialogue is limited to three options. It would be pretty cool to be able to write our own messages and have the characters be able to respond accordingly to them. Of course, that would require a much more complicated API that is likely out of the scope of a one-man indie team. But who knows? Maybe there will be such an API one day that's easy to use. Then Seeley can make another sequel. That would be awesome! If you read this, Kyle, and that kind of AI becomes possible, please make another sequel! Here's someone who will play it in a heartbeat!

I also think it would be interesting if we could talk to the other people as well. It's fun to talk to Emily and Evelyn, but what about like Kelly and Jackie? I have to wonder what they think of these situations. Or what about Emily's troubles from Jeff's perspective? And Steve's opinion on his relationship with Evelyn? That would be much more work, but I think it would add to the game's immersive experience.

Overall, I think there are a lot of good things about this game. If it means anything, I've played this game over and over in the last several weeks because of how engaging it is. I definitely recommend it.

[spoiler] Evelyn for life <3 [/spoiler]

Over a decade later, I get to live vicariously through this game to get out this friend zone.

Mission accomplished.


(This is a more refined version of 'Emily is Away', with well-integrated online features. This is a fun game/interactive story that captures the spirit of online friendships/relationships via an instant messaging interface. The writing can be clunky in places, as if these schoolmates never see each other or talk to each other face to face in between chapters. However, the narrative development is brisk and clear enough to keep you interested.)

Let me tell you that this game grasps the concept of being a teenager in the early years of the 00s so well that it was making me physically hurt as I remembered the history of myself. However it fails at the simpliest thing and that is how-.. Simple it is. 

There is no "Maybe" in this game, it is a corridor where you'll say yes and no to someone to keep moving. At the end, it'll add it up to determine if the one time you said NO was a lie or not, even if your opinion was middle ground upon it and as such, you'll encounter a bad ending. I really want to recommend this game but honestly, it's fickle and short. Maybe on sale? I don't know.

In the end, I didn't enjoy my time with it and it left me with a bitter taste in my mouth, even more so than the first. With that? I do not recommend this game.

35635226.review: An absolute joy to experience, Emily is Away too's dedication to the time period is beyond commendable.  A real joy down memory lane, if you experienced AIM back in the day (guessing that would be one of the major draws to play it in the first place) you are in for a real treat.  I typically do not write reviews, however from the second I clicked on the first "youtoob" link and got to see a recreation of the site from 2006 I was hooked.  After playing the first game (which was free) the developers could have slapped something together and simply released it at it's $5 price point and I probably would have still bought it.  That is certainly not the case, as it is clear from the onset that experience and authenticity is taken very seriously.  There is so much content these days that attempt to exploit Nostalgia for monetary gain alone.   Thankfully Emily is Away too takes you back to this time is such a genuine and honestly heartfelt way that it is not hard to find yourself walking down memory lane as the dialogue and story unfolds before you.  The game/simulation exceeds in everything it sets out to do.

35603656.review:
"Emily, who is emily?
My mother would say she's everyone.
Every girl, every boy, every person
that anyone has ever loved"

[h1]O JOGO[/h1]

 Continuando a história do primeiro jogo, Emily is Away Too desenvolve muito bem as 2 personagens com quem você interage durante o jogo e deixa bem clara a diferença de personalidades entre as duas, para que no desenrolar do jogo, você desevolva uma preferência por uma ou por outra. Cada uma das personagens tem seu próprio drama pessoal, seu próprio gosto musical, e sua prórpia prefêrencia de tipos de filmes e jogos, sendo que os gostos do jogador, ou seja, os seus gostos vão alterar o que elas sentem por você. Cada frase, cada escolha vão alterar a forma como elas te tratam e o que pensam de você. 

[h1]JOGABILIDADE[/h1]

 Basicamente a mesma coisa do primeiro com algumas melhorias que são usadas para alterar o rumo da história, como por exemplo se uma das personagens está falando algo com você e a outra te chama para falar uma coisa importante, você vai ter um tempo (curto) para escolher com qual das duas você vai falar, e isso vai alterar o seu relacionamento com elas (o que altera a história do jogo).

[h1]O MUNDO DO JOGO[/h1]

 Uma coisa muito boa em Emily Is Away Too é todo o universo que eles te proporcionam, muitas vezes a Emily ou a Eva vão te mandar músicas pra assistir no YouToob, ou te pedir para adicioná-las no FaceNook, sites criados pela própria empresa do jogo com links reais, vídeos reais e perfis reais, todos pixelados do mesmo jeito que o próprio jogo. Ou, às vezes elas vão te mandar prints de conversas para você baixar e ver, e você baixa e os arquivos aparecem na sua área de trabalho. Tudo isso faz você sentir que você está dentro daquele mundo conversando com a Emily e com a Evelyn.

[h1]CONSIDERAÇÕES FINAIS[/h1]

 Emily Is Away Too te amarra na trama durante toda a gameplay, te joga naquele universo da internet de 2006, possui vários Easter Eggs à outros jogos e desenhos e ainda é um jogo bem divertido de se jogar.

35229430.review:
[b]Facenook for college? Pfff nah man.[/b]

We all talk online nowadays as we are connected to anyone that has access to the internet and willing to talk to you or post something. When you’re not with your friends in person, why not talk to them long distance so you can talk even more. This is what Emily is Away Too goes on during the years on 2006 and 2007.

We come in on our Senior year of high school and we made two key friends that we talk to during the course of the game: Emily and Evelyn. Once you setup your username and choose an avatar, it is time to hit them up. From the beginning, there is a sense of getting to know the other person and starting out as friends as conversations with both start up asking about little things like music choice. As we go on, they get more open to talk to us about their relationship troubles and ask for advice. There is a connection there that makes you want to hear them out and if they want to spill their troubles, there is a high chance you will want to be there for them.

Sadly, the use of having two girls to talk to, there are forced situations to make you choose one. There are situations that the game that does not want you to keep up the same kind of relationship you have with the other girl. One of the most notable ones is when both are in a vulnerable spot and want you to be there for both of them at the same time. The catch? [spoiler]They are both messaging you at the same time. Of course we must all be thinking that it is not hard to keep up two conversations, you might be able to do more with your own friends and well we were able to message them at the same time in the previous chapters, but this time we have a timer. Each time you try to juggle both conversations, the timer gets shorter and shorter till one runs out and either Emily or Evelyn gets mad at you “not being there”. If you let the timer run out twice they will log off in a huff, even though you would be writing right before the timer ran out.[/spoiler]

I do get what this was trying to do, but it just falls into being forced and it takes away from wanting to care about the conversation if you want to answer both of them. Especially when the responses you give are mundane. I do think this section could of been worked better, perhaps having you choose your answers carefully, not wanting them feel like you don’t care or perhaps have something that you can actually mix up names. Or even be able to hook up with both and since you can easily guess they will [spoiler]meet up with each other someday since it is very obvious you three go to the same school and this plays a part in one of the endings[/spoiler]. 

There is also the fact that they do overreact to seemingly small things and you can’t explain yourself. They mention that it is totally okay to not have future plans set in stone and okay to change...but then you find out it’s only for them. There is a situation when one of them does something out of character and say people can change, but when you change your own choices (or you interpret the different wordings of the questions differently) it is automatically set to you being a manipulative liar. No way to explain yourself as it is an automatic failure (dumping you) as early as chapter one.

I often find that both seem too similar. They are fleshed out but not in a way that really separates the two. Their interests and how they talk are different, but they both have problems with another boy and both stories rely on which girl you choose and what response you told them. There are a few side characters, but they don’t get any character other than knowing that they could of had any name, one time which I mixed up the names since we have no way to know who they are other than when they cause conflict with the girls. Perhaps this could of been solved with you being able to talk with these side characters yourself. There is also the fact that no matter who you end up with, both Emily and Evelyn will have the same dialogue and reaction with a few things being replaced with a choice you provided and names. 

If you previously played Emily is Away, there is another huge difference that was added. Instead of being completely confined in the instant messenger window, there are a bunch of website links that were made just for this game. You will mostly get Youtube (YouToob) and Facebook (Facenook) page links during your gameplay, but there is a list of links available to see all of the websites..

[h1]Overall[/h1]
+ Cool to see that a bunch of websites are available alongside the game
+ Realistic writing
+ More secret icons with few of them having secret conversations

+/- Reusing text for Emily or Evelyn route
+/- Emily/Evelyn overreacting over small things
+/- Underdevelopment of side characters that relate to Emily/Evelyn’s story

- Forced sections where you have to fail
- Some responses don’t fit what you are roleplaying as (or the response changes to make it mean something else)

If you want to get more out of the free experience Emily is Away gave or interested in this way of storytelling, go ahead and try out Emily is Away Too. However, despite that this game made me want to care for both Emily and Evelyn there are a number of things that make the experience worse such as some of the force segments. Despite most of this review being criticisms, this game was enjoyable, but will overall provide a different feeling and meaning than Emily is Away. So I do also recommend playing the first Emily is Away game (it's free!).

35155514.review:
[h1] Возвращение к школьным проблемам [/h1]

Emily is away too - продолжение многим полюбившейся Emily is away, является таким себе симулятором общения в интернете. Наверное щас каждый общается с кучей людей с любой точки земного шара, но уверен что большинство людей вспомнит ламповые вечера общения со своими школьными друзьями. Эта игра берёт не только ностальгией из-за культуры 2006-2007, но и самим процессом общения. Наверное каждый помнит как первый раз в школе влюблялся, как хотел общаться с этим человеком, а потом всё же в большинстве случаев оставался ни с чем. В отличии от первой части, которая в 100% случаев так и делала, тут всё же можно добиться отношений, причём на выбор уже не одна девушка, а две. Обе девушки имеют разные вкусы, разные жизненные позиции, разные в общении (До определённого момента). А теперь хватит со вступлением, перейдём к плюсам и минусам. 

[h1] Плюсы [/h1]
-Вариативность
-Визуальный стиль
-Множество новых геймплейных фич (Да, с первой части много чего добавили)
-Наконец возможность зайти дальше, чем френдзона (Спасибо за разбитое сердце Эмили из первой части)
-Мелкая цена
-Ну и конечно же, множество отсылок к культуре 2006-2007 года и даже современной (Почти все в секретных аватарах, которые в этот раз ещё и дают доступ к новому собеседнику, даже есть возможность пояснить Джеффу Каплану за плохих тиммейтов в Овервотче)

[h1] Минусы [/h1]
-Всё же в конце девушки начинают максимально похоже отвечать на ваши действия (Прошёл на все концовки и заметил, что под конец девушки начинают отвечать очень схоже, с разницой только в одном-двух словах).
-Длительность
-Отсутствие локализации на русский (Но английский там не самый лёгкий, так что с базовыми знаниями должно быть довольно кофортно)


Emily is away too, как и её предшественица - игра не для всех. Тут нет нон стоп экшона, нет рпг системы, но в этой игре действительно чувствуется душа разработчика. Во время игры вливаешься в процесс, начиная думать что действительно разговариваешь со своими подругами. Определённо полезный опыт для любого человека возраста 14-19 лет, который поможет научиться разговаривать с девушками (Но это не точно). Советую брать даже без скидки, ибо 3 бакса для такой игры - довольно таки маленькая цена. :3

35122327.review:
I realize that people will have vastly different reactions to Emily is Away Too depending on how involved they were during the time period, their age, location, and whether or not they enjoy visual novels at all, but for five dollars I highly recommend you give it a shot. 

For three and a half hours, for better or worse, I was a teenager again. Kyle Seeley conjured a near-perfect snapshot of how it felt to be part of that internet community in the mid-2000s where all you had to do in order to avoid someone was setting your status to Away (or if it was really serious, Invisible). With songs that suddenly made me worry about my acne, how best to write that IM to my friend, and how my history exam would go, I found myself fully engrossed in the interactive story. 

Upon finishing the game (of which there are multiple endings), I'm hugely grateful that this game exists both as a trip down memory lane and as a story of its own. I'm also extremely glad I'm no longer a teenager.

35059279.review:
[h1] A nice little nostalgic game [/h1]

Emily is Away Too surprised me in a positive way. I played the first game and knew I'd have a similar reaction to the second, but I'd say the details caught my attention. I appreciate the effort the author had to build websites similar to those of the past just so we could have a deeper immersion. For me in particular, listening to "Open Your Eyes" when it came up was just great I never really stopped to listen to the song before, but doing so brought an overwhelming feeling of nostalgia, as if it had been with me throughout important moments of my life and I just didn't bother to notice before.
Obviously, the game wants you to feel nostalgic and immersed, it wants you to think you're back at that time when you could simply live a romance and enjoy your own innocence. I'd say that was well done.

Still, I have some problems with it as well. First, just like the first game, it seems to be designed for a male audience only. You can put a feminine name and stuff, but some moments seem plain weird when you're acting like a girl, it messes with the immersion. Also, why not let the character interact with a male NPC? Or with someone else who isn't a possible love interest? I know that there are limitations, but doing it that way made me feel as if Evelyn was there mostly to compete with Emily for your consideration. Why love [u] has [/u] to be the main goal, as the game seems to suggest?
Another issue with the game, at least in my opinion, is the need of absolute consistency. I'm not a native english speaker, but I got my first (bad) ending not because I [spoiler] lied to Emily about not wanting a family, but because I interpreted it differently in each context [/spoiler], and so did my girlfriend. This [spoiler] "I'll break up with you if anything you told her does not match what you told me" [/spoiler] leaves no room for the player to explain. It should be harder if you messed up, but not impossible if it was just a bit. And besides, people can change their minds.
But I think what really bothered me was the fact that [spoiler] no matter which of them you end up with, it's about the same dialogue and reactions once you do everything right. Emily and Evelyn are quite different from each other, and that has to remain consistent [/spoiler].

I think I wanted this game to go deeper, but it's not like I was expecting that in the first place. I'm happy enough with what was done and would recommend to anyone I felt could enjoy it.

34582754.review:
Emily is Away Too is a very curious story-driven "internet messenger simulator", so to speak. It's a paid sequel to an earlier free project Emily is Away, and has the same basic premise - exploring how friendship/relationships evolve and change as time flies. While the original game was a bit finicky and was a bit harder to suspend disbelief or care about characters due to the yearly gaps in conversations, the sequel enhances the basic idea to something truly amazing. First of, you don't need to pretend-type now with the option to just auto-fill your replies, which makes it feel less tedious and more in pace with the events. Secondly, it makes the gaps in conversations much shorter and each chapter more meaningful by having two main contacts/characters to interact with.

Now, you may, as I have, still have some troubles just due to the nature of the game - as someone who's friendships and even relationships spent a lot of time in online talking in messengers of various kinds, as someone who never considered internet a separate thing and as someone who's musical choices go more in line with the avatars in the game rather than choices you can actually set for preferences, there are moments where I just went "ugh", because the game was forcing me to be a character, rather then a virtualised version of me, which the whole narrative really wanted to achieve. But, despite all that, despite the inability to juggle two person's issues in the game (something that I managed to do in real life at times -_-), I cared. I really REALLY cared. The story was exaggerated and went along rather strict rails depending on strict choices you can do, sure. But it felt like an expert from life, just something that could've happened and something that actually happened in one or another way. And for that, especially given the very low price of the game, I cannot recommend giving Emily is Away Too a go enough - you should give it a few hours of your life. Either to experience something you never had, or to re-experience echos of something that you might've. Or even find something that is happening with you right now.

Emily is away too was an enjoyable experience, though honestly I have to question the *Multiple choices* aspect of it. While your choices very much do make an impact on some things, the character's endings lack individuality. I'm not going to spoil anything, however I will say that don't expect much of a difference in the end between the two; It's mostly like rereading the same conversation you had with either female. 

I was hoping there be a little bit of differences, seeing as the Emily and Evelyn are meant to be different girls entirely; Them having dealt with different experiences and in general just seeming like total opposites. So I won't lie and say that part of the game wasn't a little dissapointing to me. 

Still I'll give this game a solid 7 out of 10- Like I said the experience was enjoyable. Also the little easter eggs with some of the icons did make me laugh. (Rick and Morty's especially made me Lol.)

So while Emily is Away Too did have a few things for me to nitpick, I'll still recommend it. If you enjoy a slower game that mostly deals with relationship issues, drunk texts and the stress of trying to frantically switch between IMs. You'll enjoy this game.

34359161.review:
I hate this game.
It made me sad.
And I don't appreciate that.

In all seriousness, the first Emily is Away was a great experience, bringing a great look and feel to a game that brings you right into the mind of a high schooler/college student, simply using the AOL style conversations between them and their friend Emily. It's amazingly immersive, despite only ever showing you the chat window.

Emily is Away Too is like if you took the first game and made it a million more times immersive and absorbing. It became more and more of a full experience, set back in 2006 and 2007 as you were able to open links that would open to recreated versions of YouTube and Facebook in your computer's browser, it would put files to your desktop like chatlogs, making the game the actual chat program. Of course, a game like this can't be simply on its visual and immersive experience-- the story is just as heartwrenching, if not as heartwrenching as the first. It makes you feel like you've messed up if you get the ending I did on my first playthrough (and yes, that does mean I went back for another, hoping to get the good ending-- that is, if there is one). Balancing two people feels like a high school relationship, not sure how having two close friends is going to go. 

Now for some spoilers (hope the formatting works):

[spoiler] Holy shit, this game made me angry and sad, all together. I'll share my experience, mostly because I need to do something with all these emotions this game threw at me. I said one differing opinion between the two girls, and was able to date Emily. Evelyn went away, came back, and in the final chapter, ruined my relationship-- in pure Emily is Away fashion: outside the chat window, where you don't see anything. The fact that you can make a minor screwup and have that ruin the experience feels real, despite a little irrational (but, I suppose that adds to the realism). I'm in the middle of another playthrough as I write this. I better get Emily, or I'm just going to be more depressed. [/spoiler] 

I hate this game, and I love it.

Tout y est.

Les légères fautes, tantôt involontaires, tantôt pures effet de style.
Les hésitations, les messages que l'on écrit avant de se raviser, de les reformuler pour ne pas sembler trop entreprenant, ou bien encore pour laisser transparaître de possible sous-entendus.
Le passif-agressif, auquel se prête si bien la messagerie instantanée, la provoc', le tâtonnement, tenter de deviner ce que pense l'autre de soi. 
La ponctuation et les majuscules, peu souvent présentes et moyen efficace d'exprimer son sérieux, son mécontentement, d'essayer de se faire plus sec ou même cassant.
Les relectures de logs en format html, le partage de ceux-ci parfois...
Les dramas amoureux d'adolescents.

Ayant relu mes propres archives de ce temps là, je le confirme - tout y est.
Ce jeu ainsi que le premier sont la quintessence de l'époque révolue d'MSN, et je me suis pris une bonne claque de nostalgie au cours de mes différentes tentatives.

34192710.review:
[h1] This! Is! Awesomesauce! 	[/h1]

There's a lot to like about this game:

[list]
    [*]It's mostly a text-based messaging sim, so it's simple and easy and mostly fun to play.
    [*]The endings vary from happy to bittersweet to catastrophic.
    [*]A full game takes me two hours or so; after you've played once, you can start over or replay from any completed chapter.
    [*]Emily and Evelyn have distinct personalities and (for the most part) unique issues. They surprised me more than once. [spoiler] While I have much more in common with Emily, when I get together with Evelyn she seems to fall harder for me. [/spoiler]
    [*]You can try to date either Emily or Evelyn, or you can try to stay friends with them, and either way can work.
    [*]I actually learned from playing this game. The first time I played, I was too agreeable in making conversation and inadvertently made one inconsistency between what I told Emily and what I told Evelyn, which caused Emily to flip out and cut off our friendship. I played again and learned to be more willing to let my friends know when I don't see things the way they do.
    [*]The characters will send links to parody versions of Facebook and YouTube, including actual YouTube videos of great songs from 2006-7. The videos autoplay, so you can use them as a soundtrack to your messaging with Emily and Evelyn. And don't forget to check the links of the other people on your buddy list.
    [*]The game has so many nice little touches. For example, in each chapter you customize your messaging profile with song lyrics and movie quotes. The girls will then react to what you've put on your profile. [spoiler] In Chapter 4, if either girl becomes your girlfriend, she'll change her away message to the song lyrics from your profile. [/spoiler]
    [*]The nostalgia! However old you are, if you're out of high school, this game will remind you of earlier days, even if your real-life high school days were nowhere near as interesting as your senior year in this game.
    [*]Emily will send you a link to a Snow Patrol video. If you let it autoplay, the next video is Snow Patrol's "Spitting Games," which I used to hear all the time while playing MVP Baseball 2004. So it's like a video game giving me nostalgia for video games.
    [*]Did I mention the happy endings? And they're actually easy to get to as long as [spoiler] you're consistent with what you tell Emily and Evelyn and don't contradict yourself. You don't even have to agree with the girls or share their interests, as long as you're consistent. [/spoiler]
[/list]

If you've already played the original Emily is Away (I played Emily Too first), the biggest differences are a new Emily, the addition of Evelyn, the compression of time to senior year of high school instead of senior year plus college, and the possibility of multiple endings including happy ones. Plus the great music. Even Evelyn's punk songs weren't too bad.

I played this game four times as soon as I got it. After that, some aspects start to get repetitive, so I doubt that I'll replay it as often, but I'm sure I'll go back to it every now and then for a quick pick-me-up. And in the future this game will even give me nostalgia for the past times I played it.

Highly recommended.

34160489.review:
Emily is Away Too is the second to the original Emily is Away game, which I had played months prior to the purchase of this game. The game follows your interaction between yourself, Emily, and Evelyn through an oldschool texting format. You learn about them, the problems they face, and how you can provide comfort for them.

It seems basic enough, how did this game capture my attention, and my emotions, then?

In the game, you interact with both Emily and Evelyn in a first-person perspective, from the player, and depending on how you respond to them, it effects their dialogue, which in turn more effectively become attached to the characters, and their personalities. The story, the problems, the way they texted reflects how people commonly interact with each other through text, which also goes to show how much effort was put into this game to capture realism.

As for the story itself, without spoiling it, I must say it was very entertaining, and I felt drawn to the characters as I went through the chapters. The game successfully drew out my emotions, and my compassion for both Emily and Evelyn.
Really, seeing as how this game made me emotional, which so few games do now a days, it really goes to show how much of a gem this is. Outstanding work, devs!

(Spoilers)
[spoiler]As I went through my first playthrough, I had not taken much into consideration of Evelyn and Emily "remembering" my options, and thus, after getting caught in a few lies in the second chapter, it ultimately effected my outcome on the final chapter when everything was going smoothly with Emily, when that lie caught up to my character, resulting in a break-up. But what really put the nail in the coffin was the fact that she used the same advice that I had given to her to handle the Jeff situation. 

This, in turn, upset me. I began to look through the chat logs on all chapters to see where I went wrong, and after seeing the mistake that was made, I began the game over again, slugging through the dialogue (occasionally selecting new dialogue for new perspective), I achieved my desired outcome, and I was put at ease.[/spoiler]

34138560.review:
Spoiler free review! Both for this game and the first!

Now to start off this review is that I got this game for like 2 dollars on the steam market, off sale right now it is 5 dollars. This may seem like a lot for a simple click and typing game yet that is not the case, here is how I view it. People will pay millions to own pieces of art, millions more to have custom pieces of art, and normal people will pay like 20 dollars to go into an art museum. This game is only 5 dollars and many, including myself, would consider this game a work of art. Not that it's visually appealing to the eyes or anything, but that it tells a simple story, one of love, in a masterful style. So please before you read further into this review don't let the price of the product in mention deter you from purchasing it, there are plenty of Triple A games at 60 dollars that tell little to no story and have mediocre gameplay at best.

Now I personally haven't played the first game before this one, I saw this game on sale for cheap and I enjoyed the aesthetic of the 2006 era and the IM gameplay mechanic so I picked it up. I didn't play it right away but I wished I had since I enjoyed it so much. I went into this game expecting little which is how everyone who plays it should, this will provide you with little to be disappointed on. How the previously aforementioned Triple A games thrive on hype and expectations this game does the opposite, feasting on a player cluelessness for the mechanics and how to interact with fellow characters, which may or may not come back to bite you in the end. 

The gameplay is rather simplistic, talk to two girls. Simple stuff like what music they like, what games they enjoy, what they do in their free time, past relationships, sexual history. You talk to just two, Emily and Evelyn, I'm not going to share their characteristics since that's for the player to find but they vary so differently that any person should be able to relate to at least one of them. This game has 5 chapters each relatively long, the game makes use of every chapter very well for character exposition but three stand out. The first chapter is when you first meet these girls and start forming opinions, the third is the height of the story where you have to make a choice, and lastly, you end at five where it all comes to an end.

I've played this game a total of three times, each time coming in at around 4 hours. The first playthrough I never once took a break and completed it in one sitting, I received a relatively good ending but no matter which character one ends up they always ask the same question at the end. For the sake of spoilers, I won’t say it since I myself wasn’t exactly prepared for it and it’s best if you aren’t either. The question is quite a simple one, dealing with the relationship of said character and how long it would last. There are two choices. Neither has an easy answer, with knowledge with a long standing relationship would tell you.

I chose the one that everyone picked, according to the ending and the statistics that it gives every player. 97.3% of players chose the same as me, yet it felt wrong, that the other option was better, that is what this game is so great at doing. Emily is Away Too Harnesses the power of player’s past relationships, which allows for these same players to constantly argue what is the best option, it also harnesses one’s preference in a girl. 
I replayed a second time, wishing to go for the other girl and to get the ending right with the correct answer to the “Question”. However this playthrough I feel flat, I hadn’t really grasped gameplay mechanics, which was ultimately my downfall. I ended with no relationship, on both sides of the spectrum, I had no friends or any girlfriend at the end of this playthrough. This ultimately left me feeling as empty as I did with my first playthrough, if not more.

I replayed for a third time, which this game highly encourages, to get my “Goldilocks Ending” where everything is perfect. I took some self-discipline to beat the game for the third time when little to nothing changes, but I got through to the ending. At the ending of it all, with my new love interest, she sprung the “Question” this time I was prepared for and I answered right this time.

The ending song that I love so much “LCD Soundsystem-All of My Friends” purely because of this game. I cried a little, shed a few tears, and started writing this review. I can’t say how much I love this game, I would recommend this to anyone who has had some form of love that didn’t work in their life. Whether it be a secret crush that you didn’t have the courage to admit, or a perhaps a long-lasting relationship that seemingly ended for no reason, maybe a relationship right now that has some hardship. Although I give this game a lot of praise and so do others for the sake of yourself and the game, do not expect too much and you will learn to love it as I did.

34019640.review: A cada passo dado, caminhamos por um corredor escuro, tentando imaginar o que está no breu. Fazemos planos sobre o que o futuro nos reserva, mas não sabemos o que ocorrerá até, efetivamente, chegarmos lá. Esse jogo, em um mix de "quick time events" e "text adventure" te faz voltar (ou a depender de sua idade, vivenciar) o período da vida em que tentávamos advinhar o que o futuro nos reservava ou apenas aguardar sua vinda. Os elementos de nostalgia se resumem a referências à época que, através do fundo musical opcional (eles até fizeram uma versão vintage do youtube) recheado com aquelas músicas remetentes à época cartártica da adolescência dos anos 2000. A jogabilidade é simples: você escolhe uma linha de resposta à mensagem da garota e simula uma digitação. As vezes, para dar "mais emoção", você tem um tempo limitado para digitar, sob a penalidade de sua interlocutora achar que você não tem consideração por ela e te esculachar. Certamente, como todo "text adventure", a história é o forte e por sua razão eu coloquei essa frase melosa no início. Seu protagonista é um adolescente e entra em contato com essas duas garotas. Cada uma tem uma personalidade diferente, com gostos artísticos diferentes. Cabe a você escolher qual, se quiser ficar com alguma, você terá como seu amorzinho adolescente. Diferentes escolhas resultam em resultados diferentes e sua percepção de ambas as garotas também acaba por mudar no decorrer do jogo, daí a imprevisibilidade do futuro. Comecei meu primeiro playthrough convencido a acabar com a Emily, mas, em decorrência de fatos que ocorrem na narrativa do jogo, acabei por mudar o foco para a outra garota. Então em decorrência dessa reviravolta, acabei com um final diferente quando foquei em tentar ficar com as duas em meu segundo playthrough. O jogo é bom. Entrar na máquina do tempo nostálgica e lembrar da meu período "teen" valeu a pena. A ambientação (o uso da versão genérica do "MSN", as músicas do Artic Monkeys, os ícones e as citações), tal como a história interativa são os pontos altos do jogo, de forma que, perante a proposta e a intenção de jogo, o jogo alcança a qualidade de seu objetivo. A pluralidade de finais é boa também, apesar de que o fato de que alguns são decididos apenas por decisões no fim do jogo faz com que o sentimento de consequência seja abandonado. Fora esse detalhe, o jogo atinge sua proposta. Se sua intenção é jogar uma aventura em texto e sentir nostalgia, jogue "Emily is Away Too".

33762834.review: Emily is Away Too is a brand new story featuring new characters and multiple different endings. Message your friends, surf the web and choose your path through this branching narrative. This game looks simple and lazily made at first, but pretty soon it hits you by being actually awesome. It's an "AOL chat simulator", where you're messaging two friends. They message you with all sorts of files and web links (click those, they're cool), and after a while this just feels like a natural conversation. Best part is the story that unfolds via this messaging. It feels well written and very responsive to your choices. My ending felt very strong and left me somewhat in disarray, but in a good way.

33760244.review:
Emily is Away was a standout game to me at it's release, something I really couldn't compare to anything else. Yes, it's a visual novel/dating sim of sorts, but honestly, it left behind so much of what defines those genres. It did away with character sprites and multiple locations in lieu of an interface that did all the storytelling for you; an early 2000's AOL Instant Messenger chat window. The goal? To maintain a relationship with a girl named Emily, wether that be friends, enemies, or romantic. You still chose between three dialogue options to see where the relationship took you over the course of years, but even with such straightforward gameplay the game had a level of complexity and emotion games with ten times the budget couldn't emulate. I had multiple playthroughs and I STILL couldn't make the relationship with Emily work. It was so nuanced and unassuming you could trip up at nearly any point while thinking you did the right thing. Overall, the game left an impression on me and I revisited it time and time again. 

What a surprise it was to see Emily is Away Too in the Steam Store. I didn't even think a sequel was in the works but here we are and with a flew playthroughs under my belt I'm more than happy to say it does what any good sequel should; builds and improves upon an already strong foundation. The AIM window is still our main tool, but this time we aren't only talking to Emily (a different Emily than in the first game, might I add) but a new girl named Evelyn who also catches our fancy. Yet again, we can choose to pursue a friendship or a romantic relationship with either girl but maintaining two relationships is a balancing act that the game won't let you take lightly. This itteration of the game includes timed sequences where you only have so long to type replies before it just skips any answer at all, links to various early youtube videos the girls send you to talk about things they enjoy (which the youtube and facebook pages are all meticulously recreated in pixel format). and even more hidden icons to win over the course of your playthroughs. Everything about this installment is just as painstakingly thought of as the first and it's a unique and emotional experience to have.

My props to the game creator Kyle Seeley for this game series. It hits on nostalgia of the early internet but also makes use of it by making the player form deep and complicated relationships with it's equally complicated protagonists. If their is a third game in our future I eagerly await to talk to Emily again.

33674439.review:
Fourth wall is away.

Emily is Away Too is a game cleverly disguised as an instant messager just like the first game (which is for free and you should get it), but this time, they removed the fourth wall by adding in desktop backgrounds (not in-game, you change them on your computer), hyperlinks (not in-game, you browse the internet while playing the game), file sending (not in-game, they're downloaded on your computer) and a longer, arguably better story (yes, this one's in-game). Once again, you're graduating a high school and talking to your friend Emily, but this time, there's also Evelyn.

The game has you talking to them by choosing one of 3 dialogue options, but this time, choices actually matter. Besides a few choices that affect what ending you get, there's also plenty of interesting stuff that's easy to miss. My favourite example is one of the conversations with Evelyn ending with her having to take a shower, at which point one of the possible things to say is "Shower, like, naked?" Obviously I thought this was flipping hilarious and said it, which then added a couple more lines to the dialogue with her trying to crack a joke to take the conversation away from your sadly awkward social skills. Obviously, the story is different too in this one, and you can even get a happy ending this time!

The achievements in this one are for finding secrets, and full completion requires around 5 hours.

The subtleties in the dialogue, hidden chats, many links to explore and lots and lots of cool moments make this, in my opinion, far better than the first one, and, even though you have to pay this time, I'd say it's absolutely worth it.

From the beginning of the game, I kind of went with Evelyn. I liked her music style and personality way better than Emily, who is basically a copy of the Emily of the first game. Then the third chapter came, and you have to talk to both of these people at the same time, with a timer. I tried to talk to both of these people at the same time, since, even though Evelyn was way better than Emily in my opinion, I didn't want to lose my friendship with her. That's right, I felt like I was emotionally attached to these people. But I f*cked up.  The timing thing wasn't even the hardest, I knew how to keep the conversation going, but I made one mistake, messing up the two conversations with Evelyn. This hurt her so much that she went offline. I finished the chapter and "signed off" as well, feeling broken about how I just lost what felt like a best friend to me. I finished it a few days later, being awkward with Evelyn and ending up with a relationship with Emily, but something still felt sour with me.
[/spoiler]

So yeah, play this game if you enjoy story-driven games or visual novels.

33626127.review:
WARNING: SPOILERS AHEAD! Also this review gets kind of sappy, so like, beware lol.


This game is very personal for me. I myself am pretty young, having been these character's ages not too long ago myself. I didn't really have monumentous expectations for this game, I only picked it up because I felt the first one was a neat proof of concept. I got through the first chapter, was impressed enough, and just kind of thought it would stick to that charming AoL chat simulator thing it had going on for the remaining few chapters. But it was in the second chapter I began realising, wait, I've been here before. Like, not on AoL, I missed that age by a few years. No, I'd been in these friendships. And I'd felt these things for these exact people. Well, not LITERALLY them - people who were just like them. People I KNEW. They represented people who breathed, and existed tangibly, and I KNEW. And as every chapter did its thing, and carried me further into this all too familiar story, I started to get nervous. I knew what was coming at the end, even if I'd felt like I'd done everything I'd needed to do to avoid it. Like, I was honestly tracing back and forth in my mind, "Have I done something wrong? Did I ever let her down, was I making it too much about me in one chapter?" I didn't even really think about how silly that was, to be so concerned about fictional girlfriends, and hell putting it like that it does sound pretty pathetic. I wasn't really concerned about whether I'd illed Evelyn, I was concerned because Evelyn was a photocopy of someone I dated when I was young, and I dated this video game character like I'd dated them, and I knew how that went down. And sure enough, there I was, in chapter 5 - I was reliving the worst breakup of my life all over again.  That's a good argument, I think, for this game demonstrating writing that exceeds good, because it captures real people in ways that only good games with good writers can. It's all really sappy, but I think it's supposed to be. Love is, really, usually pretty sappy and messy and pretentious. And this game gets that, and it gets it using only two characters, two chat boxes, and some fake websites. 

Toby, sorry I fucked everything up, and I'm sorry that it had to had to be you who suffered that. I hope youre happier now.
